header: Ukraine Launches Rare Missile Strikes in Russia, Moscow Says

desc: NA

header: The ‘Devil’s Playground’ of Urban Combat That Israel Is Preparing to Enter
desc: A ground invasion in Gaza could produce some of the fiercest street-to-street fighting since World War II.

header: India sends aid to Gaza as it tries to balance its ties to Palestinians and growing closeness to Israel.
desc: NA
author: By Mujib Mashal

header: Leftist Upstart Threatens to Shake Up German Politics
desc: Sahra Wagenknecht has announced a new party, which could become another populist force scrambling German politics.

header: A Qatar-owned sports network has altered its broadcasts to avoid references to the war.
desc: NA
author: By Tariq Panja

header: Fire from Israel’s vicinity ‘targeted’ and killed a Reuters reporter in Lebanon, a media watchdog finds.
desc: NA
author: By Euan Ward and Gaya Gupta

header: Here are the latest developments.

desc: Nearly 200 inmates left a high-security Russian prison to join the war in Ukraine, seeking redemption, money or freedom. Many were killed or wounded.

header: Putin to Visit Saudi Arabia and U.A.E. on Wednesday
desc: The trip is part of a series of diplomatic meetings by the Russian leader, and comes as Ukraine tries to shore up eroding Western support for its war effort.

header: On the Ground in Wars and Disasters, the U.N. Plays a Vital Role
desc: While some critics say the world body is paralyzed by political differences, its humanitarian agencies are helping needy people in Gaza and other places around the world.

header: The U.S. announces $21 million more in aid for Palestinians.
desc: NA
author: By Gaya Gupta

header: Detained in Russia for 250 Days, American Reporter Is Still Awaiting Trial
desc: Evan Gershkovich, a journalist for The Wall Street Journal, is being held on a spying charge that he, his newspaper and the U.S. government deny.

header: Ukraine Carries On Fight While Pondering an Erosion of U.S. Aid
desc: The government in Kyiv remains hopeful of further American assistance, but it is also looking to other resources — and trying to make clear what could be at stake.

header: Political Frictions Unsettle Ukraine as It Seeks More Military Support
desc: Tensions between Ukrainian leaders, including between President Volodymyr Zelensky and his military chief, come as the country seeks emergency aid from Washington.

header: Lawmakers Set the Date for Russia’s Next Presidential Election
desc: The winner of the contest is widely seen as a foregone conclusion: Vladimir V. Putin.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: E.U. Leaders in China Press Xi on Russia and Trade Imbalance
desc: The European summit with China’s leader comes as relations have cooled over Beijing’s alignment with Russia in its war on Ukraine and a surge in Chinese exports.
author: By David Pierson, Olivia Wang and Keith Bradsher

header: Girl Kills Schoolmate and Wounds 5 Others in Russia Shooting

author: By Reuters

header: The Justice Department says it is investigating the deaths of 30 Americans on Oct. 7.
desc: NA
author: By Glenn Thrush

header: How Israel Is Using Real-Time Battlefield Intelligence to Target Hamas
desc: Israel has recovered a trove of material that its military has used to assess the extent of the group’s attack plans, and its tactics and abilities, information reviewed by The Times shows.

header: Athletes From Russia and Belarus Are Cleared to Compete at Paris Olympics

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: In Soldiers’ Remains, Russia Plots a Way to Reconcile With France
desc: A man with close ties to the Kremlin went looking for and found the remains of World War I Russian soldiers in France. Moscow hopes to use the discovery for diplomatic purposes.

header: State Department bypasses Congress to approve Israel’s order for tank ammunition.
desc: It is the first time the Biden administration has declared an emergency to expedite arms shipments to the Middle East, which are controversial because of the civilian death toll from Israeli airstrikes.

header: State Department Bypasses Congress to Approve Israel’s Order for Tank Ammunition
desc: It is the first time the Biden administration has declared an emergency to expedite arms shipments to the Middle East, which are controversial because of the civilian death toll from Israeli airstrikes.
author: By Edward Wong

header: Pressure Rising on U.S. After Vetoing U.N. Call for a Cease-Fire in Gaza
desc: As fighting surged in the territory, Arab leaders condemned the move as a “mark of shame,” one that will haunt the United States for years.
author: By Vivian Nereim, Edward Wong and Thomas Fuller

header: As Zelensky Heads to Washington, Russia Targets Kyiv With Missiles
desc: The Ukrainian leader will be appealing for more military support from the United States as an emboldened Russia steps up its attacks on his country.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Netanyahu and Putin Speak, and Offer Different Versions of What Was Said
desc: It was the first call in weeks between the two leaders, whose relationship has been strained since the start of the Israel-Hamas war.

header: Despite Wars, Earthquakes and Hurricanes, U.N. Cuts Appeal for Aid
desc: With pledges already lagging badly for this year, the global organization said that it had been forced to pare down its request for 2024 to focus on only the most life-threatening cases.

header: A conference in Qatar is a venue for strong pro-Palestinian views.
desc: NA
author: By Ben Hubbard

header: As Russia Gains Confidence, a New Urgency Grips Ukraine

header: Russian Missile Attack on Kyiv Injures Dozens

header: Huge Cyberattack Knocks Ukraine’s Largest Mobile Operator Offline
desc: The interruption could pose real danger in a country where many rely on phone alerts to warn them of impending Russian bombardments.
author: By Marc Santora

header: With a New Leader, Poland Prepares for a Course Change in Europe

header: Putin ‘Banking On’ U.S. Failing to Deliver Aid to Ukraine, Biden Says
desc: President Biden said he approved more aid for critical equipment for Ukraine.
author: NA

header: Finland Partly Reopens Its Border With Russia
desc: The Nordic country, which recently joined NATO, has accused Moscow of funneling migrants to their shared land border.

header: Biden Warns Israel It Is ‘Losing Support’ Over War

header: As Egypt’s Presidential Election Closes, No Suspense Over Winner

desc: The European Union’s willingness to open accession talks will lift morale, but the more immediate prospects for financial support from allies is sobering.

header: German Spy Official Goes on Trial Accused of Selling Secrets to Russia
desc: The trial, held under stringent security conditions and expected to last months, caps one of the gravest espionage scandals in recent German history.

header: Russia’s Central Bank Raises Rates Again, to 16 Percent, to Curb Inflation
desc: The bank warned that its tight monetary policy would continue “for a long period” as it attempts to slow an economy in danger of overheating.

header: The war will worsen poverty in neighboring countries, a study predicts.
desc: NA
author: By Ephrat Livni

header: 2023 in Photos: A Weary World

author: NA

header: Friday Briefing

author: By Natasha Frost

header: Putin Quietly Signals He Is Open to a Cease-Fire in Ukraine

header: Russia Makes Small Battlefield Gains, Increasing Pressure on Ukraine

header: Indian Envoy Meets With Putin, Bypassing Western Pressure

author: By Natasha Frost

header: Wolfgang Schäuble, German Politician Who Helped Forge European Unity, Dies at 81

header: Wednesday Briefing: A Success and a Setback for Ukraine
desc: Also, the U.S. hit Iran-backed fighters in Iraq.

desc: Also, the death of a Korean actor and food predictions for 2024.

desc: The nine-year sentence reflects how the Kremlin continues to crack down on Aleksei A. Navalny’s political movement years after his organization was banned.

header: Ukraine, Stalled on the Front, Steps Up Sabotage, Targeting Trains
desc: As conventional forces struggle to break through defensive lines, both sides are increasingly turning to guerrilla tactics.

desc: The bombardment of Belgorod on Saturday, apparently in response to an enormous air assault by Moscow a day earlier, appeared to be the deadliest single attack on Russian soil since the start of the war.

header: As War Rages in Ukraine, Denmark Turns an Office Park Back Into an Arsenal
desc: The conflict and surging arms production in Russia have spurred demand for ammunition manufacturing across Europe.

header: As Missiles Fall and New Year Dawns, Putin and Zelensky Address Citizens
desc: The message of resilience offered by Ukraine’s leader, Volodymyr Zelensky’s message, contrasted sharply with that of President Vladimir V. Putin, who glossed over the war in an effort to project a sense of normality.
author: By Constant Méheut and Anton Troianovski

header: The World in Stories: 13 Favorite Dispatches From 2023
desc: Our correspondents ventured to some of the world’s most remote, and dangerous, locales to report stories that reveal a country’s culture and the human condition. Here are our favorites from the year.

header: Biden Administration Again Bypasses Congress for Weapons Sale to Israel
desc: The move comes as Israel presses on with its offensive in Gaza despite increasing pressure from the United States to lower the conflict’s intensity.

header: Russia Hammers Kyiv With Missiles in Large-Scale Attack
desc: Russia said that Ukraine retaliated hours later with missile attacks on Russian territory, part of an escalating cycle of air assaults between the two countries.
author: By Constant Méheut and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Putin Vows to Keep Up Bombardment After a Russian City Is Hit
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia says his country will continue targeting Ukrainian cities in retaliation for a deadly attack on the city of Belgorod on Saturday.

header: Buildings Smolder After Russian Air Attacks on Kyiv
desc: First responders put out fires after Russia bombarded the Ukrainian capital with missiles and drones.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Young Love Meets Russian Repression. They Said ‘I Do’ in a Moscow Prison
desc: She’s 18. He’s 23. He sent her a one-sentence letter through his prison’s electronic mail system: “Will you marry me?” They wed in a small room in a Moscow jail.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: ‘It’s State Propaganda’: Ukrainians Shun TV News as War Drags on
desc: A government-approved news program intended to counter Russian disinformation and boost morale is coming under criticism for painting a rosy picture of the war.
author: By Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk

header: A Trophy in Ruins: Evidence Grows That Russia Controls Marinka
desc: Ukraine said it was defending territory behind the eastern frontline town. Its capture would be Russia’s most significant territorial advance in Ukraine in more than six months.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Russia and Ukraine Exchange Record Number of P.O.W.s
desc: The exchange of prisoners was the first in months and came as both sides were engaged in an escalating cycle of air assaults.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Constant Méheut

desc: General Suleimani, the powerful commander heading Iran’s Quds Force, was considered a hero by some in the country. The anniversary of his death has attracted horrific violence.

desc: Ukrainian officials said missile assaults had struck private houses, trapping residents under the rubble, and that the dead included five children.

header: Exhausted, on the Defensive and at ‘Hell’s Gate’ in Ukraine
desc: The country’s forces along a broad stretch of the front say that, with Russia pushing forward, the war has never been so dangerous.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Vladyslav Golovin and Mauricio Lima

header: Russia Pounds Several Ukrainian Regions With Missiles
desc: The attack killed at least four people, wounded many others and caused heavy damage. It came as Moscow has intensified air assaults in recent days.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: ‘Two Men Down’: For Ukrainian Medics, It Was Time to Move
desc: They are the first line of treatment for soldiers wounded on the battlefield, racing against time to try to save lives.

header: Ukrainian Residential Buildings Destroyed by Russian Air Assault
desc: Some civilians sheltered in subway stations as Russia launched a widespread missile attack on regions across Ukraine.
author: By Reuters and The Associated Press

header: Francis Urges Ban on Surrogacy, Calling It ‘Despicable’
desc: The pope said that an unborn child must not be “turned into an object of trafficking,” expanding his condemnation of a practice already illegal in Italy and some other European countries.

desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is likely to find strong backing on a trip to the Baltic States, but other nations are increasingly wary.

header: At World Court, Israel to Confront Accusations of Genocide

desc: The Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, called President Biden experienced and predictable. But Moscow watchers said the comments most likely had an ulterior motive.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Thursday Briefing: Indonesia’s New Leader
desc: Also, a coalition forms in Pakistan and motorbikes pile high in Vietnam.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Avdiivka, Longtime Stronghold for Ukraine, Falls to Russians
desc: With Ukraine’s forces at risk of encirclement, the top military commander ordered a retreat. In startlingly candid accounts, soldiers described disarray and despair.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Marc Santora and Constant Méheut

header: Five Places Russia Is Fighting to Break Through Ukrainian Lines
desc: Outmanned and outgunned, Ukrainian ground forces are in perhaps their most precarious position since the opening months of the war.
author: By Marc Santora, Scott Reinhard and Josh Holder

header: What to Know About the Fall of Avdiivka
desc: Russia’s capture of a city that had been a stronghold of Ukrainian defenses in the Donetsk region is a strategic and symbolic blow.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Zelensky Visits Berlin and Paris to Shore Up Support as U.S. Wavers
desc: The Ukrainian president signed security agreements and sought to push the European leaders to bolster aid as concerns over American funding grow.
author: By Erika Solomon and Constant Méheut

header: ‘Dictators Do Not Go on Vacation,’ Zelensky Warns Washington and Europe
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky pushed back against skepticism of a Ukraine victory, calling on world leaders not to ask when the war would end, but why Russia was still able to wage it.
author: By Peter Baker, David E. Sanger and Erika Solomon

header: Navalny’s Death Raises Tensions Between U.S. and Russia
desc: President Biden condemned “Putin and his thugs” for the Russian dissident’s demise, while European allies urgently sought assurances that the United States would not abandon them.
author: By Peter Baker

header: Where does Navalny’s reported death leave Russia and Putin?
desc: The reported death of Aleksei A. Navalny ushers in a new turning point for President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia, underscoring both the Kremlin’s power and the potential for instability that continues to threaten it.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: For Ukrainians, Navalny was a controversial figure.
desc: Mr. Navalny was respected in Ukraine for his political activism, but he was also seen in a less-flattering light there because of his comments that appeared to question its territorial sovereignty.
author: By Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk

header: In Prison or Out, Navalny Was the Thorn in Putin’s Side
desc: A straight-talking former real estate lawyer, he stayed relevant even from prison, pleading with Russians not to give up or give in to their fears and railing against the “criminal” war in Ukraine.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: With Prison Certain and Death Likely, Why Did Navalny Return?
desc: An activist who thrived on agitation, he feared irrelevancy in exile. Winning new respect as he continued to lambast the Kremlin from behind bars cost him his life.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: The Death Throes of a Ukrainian City
desc: Toward the end of Russia’s long assault, hundreds of civilians still remained in Avdiivka. Those who escaped in the last weeks spoke of relentless devastation.
author: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks

header: City’s Fall Leaves Ukraine With an Even Tougher Fight Ahead
desc: After the capture of Avdiivka, Ukrainian forces will need a new defensive line in unforgiving terrain, while Russia tries to press its advantage.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: As Putin Threatens, Despair and Hedging in Europe
desc: There is a dawning recognition that the continent urgently needs to step up its own defense, especially as the U.S. wavers, but the commitments still are not coming.
author: By David E. Sanger and Steven Erlanger

header: A Stunned Russian Opposition in Exile Considers a Future Without Navalny
desc: The death of Aleksei A. Navalny in a Russian prison has been a blow to an opposition movement in which he was the figurehead. But it has also raised hopes of a united front against President Vladimir V. Putin.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Alina Lobzina

header: Hungary Snubs U.S. Senators Pushing for Sweden’s Entry Into NATO
desc: Officials in Budapest declined to meet with a bipartisan group of American lawmakers who favor expanding the military alliance.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Arrested for Leaving Flowers, Navalny Mourners Fear Worse to Come
desc: At least 366 people were detained over the weekend, leading to concern that the arrests could signal greater government repression ahead of Russia’s elections in March.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Navalny’s Death Shocked the World, but Will It Galvanize Opposition to Putin?
desc: His death united world leaders and demonstrators in grief, but it also left Russia without a charismatic counterweight to its leader’s increasingly repressive policies.
author: By Mark Landler

header: U.S. Says It Struck 5 Houthi Targets in Yemen, Including an Underwater Drone
desc: The American military said it believes it is the first time such an undersea weapon had been used in the current conflict in the Red Sea.
author: By Julian E. Barnes

header: Ursula von der Leyen Seeks Second Term as Top E.U. Official
desc: The German politician has been European Commission president since 2019, becoming a key contact for the Biden administration.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Israel’s Occupation of Palestinian Territories Draws Focus of U.N. Court
desc: Dozens of countries are expected to argue before the International Court of Justice about the legality of Israeli actions in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.
author: By Marlise Simons

header: Protesting Polish Farmers Block Much of Ukraine’s Western Border
desc: The farmers are demonstrating against what they see as an influx of Ukrainian food products crowding the Polish market and undercutting their livelihood.
author: By Anatol Magdziarz, Maria Varenikova and Emma Bubola

header: Russian Forces Press On With Attacks in Southern Ukraine
desc: The assaults on the village of Robotyne, which come at the same time as successful attacks in the east, are designed to pressure Ukrainian troops across the front line, analysts say.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Russian Pilot Who Defected to Ukraine Is Believed Dead in Spain
desc: The apparent death in Spain of Maksim Kuzminov is likely to fuel speculation that it was the work of Russia’s intelligence services.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Constant Méheut

header: Russia Arrests U.S. Citizen, Accusing Her of Treason by Aiding Ukraine
desc: The country’s main security agency said the 33-year-old detainee lived in Los Angeles. A lawyers group said she was accused of donating $50 to the war effort.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: A Russian Military Blogger Dies After Criticizing Army Losses
desc: The ultranationalist blogger, Andrei Morozov, had described a campaign of intimidation against him and threatened to end his own life.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: In Taiwan, Visiting Lawmakers Say U.S. Support Is Firm
desc: A bipartisan House delegation said the United States would stand by the island in the face of pressure from China, drawing connections between Taiwan’s cause and Ukraine’s.
author: By Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien

header: As Russia and the U.S. argue before the I.C.J., each accuses the other of hypocrisy.
desc: NA
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: U.S. Warns Allies Russia Could Put a Nuclear Weapon Into Orbit This Year
desc: The American assessments are divided, however, and President Vladimir Putin denied having such an intention, saying that Russia was “categorically against” it.
author: By David E. Sanger

header: U.S. Defends Israel’s Occupation of the West Bank at Top U.N. Court
desc: A U.S. official urged judges not to call for Israel’s withdrawal from occupied territory, arguing that Israel faced “very real security needs” and that a Palestinian state must be established for a lasting peace.
author: By Marlise Simons, Cassandra Vinograd, Neil MacFarquhar and Thomas Fuller

header: Wife, Protector and Now Political Heir: Yulia Navalnaya Rallies Russians
desc: The wife of Russia’s most famous opposition leader long shunned the spotlight, but his death in prison may make that impossible. “I have no right to give up,” she said.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Unpredictable Strongman? Two Years Into War, Putin Embraces the Image.
desc: Vladimir Putin is drawing on history to position himself in the realm of Russian rulers of the past. Critics say his grip on power is not as strong as it seems.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: For Many Ukrainians, It’s Been a 10-Year War, Not a 2-Year One
desc: Russia’s invasion came in two phases, many Ukrainians say: the first a decade ago, when it sent soldiers over the border in an unacknowledged military intervention, and the second when it began its full assault two years ago.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and The New York Times

header: Navalny’s Mother Says Authorities Are ‘Blackmailing’ Her Over Son’s Remains
desc: She said Russian authorities told her they would not release his remains unless she agreed to a “secret funeral.” Meanwhile, Aleksei Navalny’s widow met with President Biden.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Bosnia’s Dysfunction Snarls Efforts to Curb Moscow’s Reach in the Balkans
desc: The United States and Europe have championed a new pipeline to bring gas to Bosnia and cut supplies from Russia. But the project has been stalled by feuding among ethnic groups.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Navalny and the Mirage of a Different Russia
desc: Aleksei Navalny symbolized a possibility for Russia. His death symbolizes its end.
author: By Amanda Taub

header: Inside the Hospitals Treating Brain Injuries in Ukraine
desc: Two years of war produced thousands of damaged brains. We followed surgeons and soldiers on the road to recovery.
author: By Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Orban Gives Green Light to Sweden’s NATO Bid
desc: Viktor Orban, the Hungarian prime minister, said after a meeting with Sweden’s leader, and a deal for more fighter jets, that the two countries are “ready to fight for each other.”
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Friday Briefing: Two Years of War in Ukraine
desc: Also, an attempt at a moon landing.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Waiting for Serhiy
desc: After nearly two years and only scraps of information, a Ukrainian family still hopes their son, a marine captured by the Russians in Mariupol, will come home soon.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and David Guttenfelder

header: The Spy War: How the C.I.A. Secretly Helps Ukraine Fight Putin
desc: For more than a decade, the United States has nurtured a secret intelligence partnership with Ukraine that is now critical for both countries in countering Russia.
author: By Adam Entous and Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukraine Marks 2nd Anniversary of Russian Invasion, Determined Despite Setbacks
desc: European and other Western leaders gathered in Kyiv to pledge support for Ukraine amid U.S. reluctance, while its troops suffer growing losses on the battlefield, where the Russians have been gaining ground.
author: By Marc Santora

header: 31,000 Ukrainian Soldiers Killed in Two Years of War, Zelensky Says
desc: The tally that President Volodymyr Zelensky revealed on Sunday differs sharply from that given by U.S. officials, who have said the number is closer to 70,000.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Constant Méheut

header: Ukraine’s Deepening Fog of War
desc: Two years after Russia’s full-scale invasion, Ukrainian leaders are seeking a path forward in the face of ferocious assaults and daunting unknowns.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Hard Lessons Make for Hard Choices 2 Years Into the War in Ukraine
desc: Western sanctions haven’t worked. Weapons from allies are running low. Pressure may build on Kyiv to seek a settlement, even from a weakened position.
author: By Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger

header: Russia’s Brutal War Calculus
desc: The costs of two years of war in Ukraine have been enormous. But many Russians are feeling optimistic.
author: By Paul Sonne and Josh Holder

header: In Russia, Knowing That Her Son Is Dead, and Waiting for Him Anyway
desc: She watched, distressed, as Aleksei was sent off to war. Now, 14 months after he died in eastern Ukraine, Yulia Seleznyova holds a sliver of hope for a miracle.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Belarus Holds an Election, but the Outcome Is Not Hard to Predict
desc: The opposition in exile has called for a boycott of the parliamentary vote, which includes only parties that support Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, who has ruled the country for 30 years.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Fire in Valencia, Spain, Leaves Residents Homeless After Panicked Escapes
desc: A fire that killed at least 10 people left many refugees from Ukraine without homes and others scrambling to rebuild their lives.
author: By Rachel Chaundler

header: Kremlin Warns Against NATO Ground Intervention in Ukraine
desc: The warning came in response to comments by President Emmanuel Macron of France, who said “nothing should be ruled out” when asked about the possibility.
author: By Paul Sonne and Constant Méheut

header: The NATO Welcoming Sweden Is Larger and More Determined
desc: The alliance’s expansion, with Finland last year and soon Sweden, was a consequence from the invasion of Ukraine that Russia’s president may not have calculated.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: In Ukraine, Russia Is Inching Forward Death by Death
desc: Russian forces have an unorthodox view of acceptable levels of military losses, with a willingness to expend troops and equipment to make even small gains on the battlefield.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Macron Does Not Rule Out Sending Western Troops to Ukraine
desc: The French leader said that talks had not resulted in any consensus among European officials on putting troops on the ground in an “official” way, but that “anything is possible.”
author: By Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden

header: Senate Aide Investigated Over Unofficial Actions in Ukraine
desc: Kyle Parker says he delivered sniper gear as part of his unabashed support for Ukraine. Investigators say there may be “counterintelligence issues.”
author: By Lara Jakes, Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: Russian Court Jails Leading Rights Advocate for ‘Discrediting’ Military
desc: Oleg Orlov, 70, a co-chairman of Memorial, which shared the 2022 Nobel Peace Prize, was sentenced to two-and-a-half years in prison for speaking out on the Ukraine war.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Wednesday Briefing: Russia Warned Against NATO Troops in Ukraine
desc: Plus, the latest on a possible cease-fire in Gaza.
author: By Jonathan Wolfe

header: Hungary’s Parliament Approves Sweden’s NATO Bid After Stalling
desc: Budapest had been the final obstacle to the Nordic country’s joining the alliance, which has been trying to isolate Russia over its war in Ukraine.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Ego, Putin or Jets? Reasons for Orban’s Stance on Sweden Perplex Many.
desc: The Hungarian leader has given various rationales for stalling Swedish membership in NATO. The real reason may have to do with his own standing and domestic politics.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Tuesday Briefing: Hungary Approved Sweden’s NATO Bid
desc: Plus, movement in a possible Israel-Hamas deal.
author: By Jonathan Wolfe

header: Seeking to Unsettle Russia, Macron Provokes Allies
desc: The French president’s openness to Western troops in Ukraine signaled a quest for military resolve. But some allies felt blindsided.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Ukraine Charges Key Figure in Arms Trade With Corruption
desc: A Times investigation showed how the war helped Serhiy Pashinsky rehabilitate a troubled reputation. Now he faces charges related to accusations about his past.
author: By Daria Mitiuk

header: Putin Says West Risks Nuclear Conflict if It Intervenes More in Ukraine
desc: “We also have weapons that can strike targets on their territory,” Mr. Putin said in an annual speech. “Do they not understand this?”
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: New Nuclear Threats From Putin, Timed for a Moment of Anxiety
desc: Repeated threats by President Vladimir Putin of Russia to make use of nuclear weapons have become the background theme of the war in Ukraine, often timed for maximum effect.
author: By David E. Sanger

header: Russia Took the City. Now It’s Coming for Their Villages.
desc: Ukrainian farmers and miners and their families who live to the west of the recently captured Avdiivka are poised to flee in the face of a Russian onslaught.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: A Breakaway Region of Moldova Asks Russia for Protection
desc: Transnistria declared independence in 1992 but is not recognized internationally. The request by the territory’s legislature could fuel regional tensions as the war in Ukraine rages.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Surprisingly Weak Ukrainian Defenses Help Russian Advance
desc: Ukraine only built a sparse, rudimentary defensive line outside Avdiivka. Russia is taking advantage.
author: By Josh Holder, Constant Méheut, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

header: From a Funeral Image, the Textures of Faith and State in Russia
desc: The opposition leader Aleksei Navalny called himself “a typical post-Soviet believer” of Russian Orthodox faith. But the institution of the church bound itself closely to President Vladimir V. Putin.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Oleg Matsnev

header: For Navalny’s Followers, a ‘Surge of Inspiration’ at a Sad Event
desc: Although the funeral of Aleksei Navalny seemed to underline Vladimir Putin’s dominance of Russia, it was also a day when pent-up dissent, and optimism, re-emerged, if only briefly.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins

header: Why More American Weapons Will Soon Be Made Outside America
desc: With the wars in Ukraine and Gaza straining U.S. arsenals, Washington is seeking to expand production with global partners like Australia.
author: By Damien Cave

header: Thousands Turn Out for Navalny’s Funeral in Moscow
desc: The police presence appeared heavy for the service. Some attendees shouted, “No to war” and “Russia will be free” as they marched to the cemetery where the opposition leader was to be buried.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: How Germany’s Most Wanted Criminal Hid in Plain Sight
desc: Daniela Klette, a militant from the Red Army Faction, was on the run for decades. Yet with publicly available digital recognition tools, German police could probably have found her much sooner.
author: By Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Biden Says U.S. Will Begin Aid Airdrops in Gaza
desc: The president said that the United States would work with Jordan and other allies to deliver aid by air and that supplies could eventually be delivered by sea.
author: By Julian E. Barnes and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

header: Now It’s Germany’s Turn to Frustrate Allies Over Ukraine
desc: First President Emmanuel Macron of France, then Chancellor Olaf Scholz, exposed divisions among Western countries trying to avoid direct hostilities with Russia.
author: By David E. Sanger and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Russian Strike’s Toll Rises to 12 as Zelensky Blames Air Defense Delay
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky did not refer to the United States, but his words appeared to reflect frustration over a stalled American aid package.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: The U.N. team’s sexual violence report describes its members’ expertise in the field as extensive.
desc: NA
author: By The New York Times

header: Kremlin Seeks to Suppress Navalny’s Influence, in Death as in Life
desc: The Russian authorities vilified the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny with a viciousness that suggested he was more influential than Moscow would admit. Little has changed since he died.
author: By Paul Sonne and Oleg Matsnev

header: Tuesday Briefing: Trump can appear on ballots
desc: Also, France protects abortion rights and a U.N. report on sexual assault during the Oct. 7 attack.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Shift in Russian Tactics Intensifies Air War in Ukraine
desc: Moscow’s recent gains in the east have been aided by more aggressive air support on the front lines. But that also has helped Ukraine shoot down enemy planes in the past two weeks.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: International Court Accuses 2 Russian Officers of War Crimes in Ukraine
desc: Arrest warrants were issued by the International Criminal Court for two military officials, a general and an admiral, both accused of targeting civilians and destroying crucial energy infrastructure.
author: By Marlise Simons

header: Ukraine’s First Lady Declines Invitation to State of the Union Address
desc: Olena Zelenska’s office cited a scheduling conflict. The Russian opposition figure Yulia Navalnaya also declined an invitation.
author: By Constant Méheut and Michael D. Shear

header: Too Little Ammunition, Too Many Russians: The Harrowing Retreat From Avdiivka
desc: The fall of the city, when it came in mid-February, was brutal and fast. Soldiers fought for their lives. Many did not make it.
author: By Carlotta Gall, Oleksandr Chubko and Lynsey Addario

header: Russia Strikes Odesa With Missile During Visit by Zelensky and Greek Leader
desc: Neither man was hurt, and it was unclear whether the Russian Army was targeting them.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: I.M.F. Agrees to Much Larger Rescue Package for Egypt
desc: The International Monetary Fund will provide $8 billion to Egypt, which is going through its worst economic crisis in decades.
author: By Nada Rashwan

header: Egyptians Are Buying and Selling Gold Just to Stay Afloat
desc: Clamor for the precious metal is growing as the buying power of the country’s currency plunges in value against the dollar, and inflation eats away at savings.
author: By Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan

header: Thursday Briefing: Haley Drops Out
desc: Also, Israel-Hamas talks stall before Ramadan.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Wednesday Briefing: Americans Vote on Super Tuesday
desc: Also, China’s ambitious growth goal and this year’s winner of the Pritzker Prize.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: ‘Decolonizing’ Ukrainian Art, One Name-and-Shame Post at a Time
desc: Oksana Semenik’s social media campaign both educates the curious about overlooked Ukrainian artists — and pressures global museums to relabel art long described as Russian.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Crowdfunding, Auctions and Raffles: How Ukrainians Are Aiding the Army
desc: Fund-raisers are borrowing heavily from business techniques to keep donations flowing to the military. The latest trend? Broad approaches that rely on networks of friends and acquaintances.
author: By Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk

header: Zelensky Names Ukraine’s Ex-Top General Ambassador to U.K.
desc: The former top general, Valery Zaluzhny, was dismissed last month amid tensions with the civilian leadership. He has been a very popular figure in Ukraine.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Opposition Blasts Macron for Risking Escalation in Ukraine
desc: The French president attempted to forge a united front on a harder line against Russia. But few were persuaded.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: The I.C.C. Arrest Warrants for Russian Officers Will Echo Beyond Russia
desc: The warrants for two commanders over alleged war crimes may set an interesting precedent, legal experts said, including for the conflict in Gaza.
author: By Amanda Taub

header: Sweden Enters NATO, a Blow to Moscow and a Boost to the Baltic Nations
desc: With the addition of Sweden to NATO, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia finds himself facing an enlarged and motivated alliance.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Aid From José Andrés’s World Central Kitchen Could Depart for Gaza Within Days, Officials Say
desc: The organization founded by the celebrity Spanish chef has served more than 32 million meals in Gaza, and he hopes to do more.
author: By Christina Morales and Monika Pronczuk

header: The Indian Navy releases images of its rescue mission after a lethal Houthi attack on a vessel off Yemen.
desc: NA
author: By Gaya Gupta

header: ‘Crusty’ and ‘Pillowy’: How N.Y.C.-Style Bagels Made It Big in London
desc: Bakeries selling big, doughy bagels have opened to rave reviews in Britain, but some traditionalists are standing by the London “beigel.”
author: By Jenny Gross

header: A ‘Tipping Point’ for News in New Zealand
desc: “There was no single trigger that caused this,” James Gibbons, a regional executive at Warner Bros Discovery, said.
author: By Natasha Frost

header: Ukraine Could Deploy F-16s as Soon as July, but Only a Few
desc: Countries promised the fighter jets last year, but delivering them and training pilots have proved complex. Ukraine may start with as few as six, out of about 45 pledged.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Pope Says Ukraine Should Have the ‘Courage of the White Flag’
desc: His words have raised questions about whether Francis was suggesting that Ukraine surrender, but a Vatican spokesman said the pope meant “cease-fire and negotiation.”
author: By Jason Horowitz

header: ‘It’s a Way of Life’: Women Make Their Mark in the Ukrainian Army
desc: As Ukraine struggles against Russian assaults and its losses mount, there has been a surge of women enlisting, and they are increasingly volunteering for combat roles.
author: By Nicole Tung

header: Macron and Scholz, Never Close, Spar Over Policy Toward Ukraine and Russia
desc: A fraught relationship has recently turned bitter, with insults and barbs threatening European unity at a critical moment.
author: By Steven Erlanger, Roger Cohen and Erika Solomon

header: Russia’s Advance Around Avdiivka Loses Momentum After Quick Gains
desc: Ukraine has committed significant forces to defending the area, and Russian troops are now attacking across open fields with little cover.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Xi Sticks to His Vision for China’s Rise Even as Growth Slows
desc: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, believes his vision for technological dominance will keep powering the country’s ascent while the West recedes.
author: By Chris Buckley

header: Navalny’s Heirs Seek a Political Future in Russia
desc: Aleksei Navalny’s team has found a new leader in the opposition leader’s widow, Yulia Navalnaya. But Navalny’s death has so far brought little change to their insular tactics.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Monday Briefing: Biden Clashes With Netanyahu
desc: NA
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: ‘Jamming’: How Electronic Warfare Is Reshaping Ukraine’s Battlefields
desc: Drones have become a critical weapon for both sides, but a lack of coordination among troops has put Ukraine at a disadvantage.
author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Yurii Shyvala

header: Ukraine-Backed Russian Exile Groups Stage Assaults on Moscow’s Turf
desc: The attacks and drone strikes across the southern border were intended to counter President Vladimir V. Putin’s control over Russia, a leader in one of the groups said.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova

header: With Pride and Hope, Ukraine Celebrates Oscar Win for Mariupol Documentary
desc: Ukrainians say recognition for “20 Days in Mariupol” will help debunk Russian propaganda and refocus attention on the situation in Russian-occupied territories.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: From Moscow to Mumbai: Russia Pivots South for Trade
desc: Once dependent on Europe for trade, Russia has been forging new routes that will allow it to skirt Western restrictions. A planned railway through Iran could be key for those ambitions.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Sergey Ponomarev

header: Zimbabwe, After Expelling U.S. Officials, Accuses Them of Promoting ‘Regime Change’
desc: American officials say their team was in the country to assess governance issues, but was detained and interrogated before being deported.
author: By John Eligon

header: Wednesday Briefing: Turmoil in Haiti
desc: Also, more U.S. weapons for Ukraine and a looming financial crisis for dating apps
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. Moves to Crack Down on TikTok
desc: Also, uproar about a retouched royal photo and an Oscars recap.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: New U.S. Arms for Ukraine Will Help, for a Little While
desc: The $300 million package will help hold off the Russians for a few weeks, analysts say, but without far more Ukraine may go on losing ground.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Ukraine, Stalled on the Battlefield, Targets Russia’s Oil Industry
desc: Ukrainian drone strikes have been able to hit refineries deep in Russian territory, indicating a new vulnerability. But it is unclear if that will affect the fighting.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Putin, in Pre-Election Messaging, Is Less Strident on Nuclear War
desc: The Russian leader struck a softer tone about nuclear weapons in an interview with state television. But he warned that Russia was ready to strike if its “sovereignty and independence” were threatened.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Orban Endangers Hungary’s Status as an Ally, U.S. Diplomat Says
desc: The U.S. ambassador to Budapest raised the temperature in a long-running standoff, citing Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s pro-Russia, anti-U.S. stance and opposition to supporting Ukraine.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: E.U. Removes Russian Tech Tycoon From Sanctions List
desc: Yandex’s co-founder, Arkady Volozh, received rare sanctions relief after condemning Russia’s war and severing ties to the country.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Slovakia Presidential Election 2024: What You Need to Know
desc: The Slovak presidency is a largely ceremonial post but can play an important role when the president and prime minister represent opposing political camps.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Russia’s 2024 Presidential Vote: What to Know
desc: The presidential vote in Russia begins on Friday and lasts through Sunday, and although it features the trappings of a horse race, it is more of a predetermined, Soviet-style referendum.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar

header: Thursday Briefing: U.S. Targets TikTok
desc: Also, aid to northern Gaza and whimsical wooden automatons
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Friday Briefing: Putin’s Re-election
desc: Also, a top U.S. senator calls for Israeli elections.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: As Putin Pitches His Vision, Voters Avert Their Gaze From the War
desc: Vladimir V. Putin, casting himself as the only leader able to end the war in Ukraine, is all but assured another term in a rubber-stamp election this weekend.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: Rebellious Russians Stage Daring Attacks From Ukraine on Russian Soil
desc: The surprise attacks, timed to Russia’s election, are meant to undermine the sense of stability in Russia and divert the country’s military resources from Ukraine.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Russian Missile Strikes Kill at Least 20 in Odesa, Ukraine Says
desc: Two missiles hit the same spot, Ukrainian authorities said, killing some rescuers who had responded to the first attack.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: In Occupied Ukraine, Casting a Vote (for Putin) as Armed Soldiers Watch
desc: Russia is holding a presidential vote in the occupied regions of Ukraine to try to legitimize its rule there, expose dissenters and present a veneer of democracy.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Andrew E. Kramer, Oleksandra Mykolyshyn and Oleg Matsnev

header: Macron and Scholz Meet, Looking to Patch Up Differences on Ukraine
desc: The leaders of France and Germany tried to heal an increasingly public rift over their approach to the war, holding talks alongside Poland’s prime minister on support for Kyiv.
author: By Erika Solomon and Roger Cohen

header: Russians Know Putin Will Be Re-Elected, but Many Worry What Comes Next

header: Russian Deputy Defense Minister Is Detained on Bribery Charges
desc: Timur Ivanov, who has long been in charge of major military construction projects and known for leading a lavish lifestyle, was held Tuesday on charges of “large scale” corruption.

header: Germany Arrests Aide to E.U. Lawmaker on Suspicion of Spying for China

header: Blinken Goes to China With Potential Trouble on Horizon

header: Tuesday Briefing: The Trump Trial Opens

author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: ‘Kharkiv Is Unbreakable’: A Battered City Carries On

header: Enduring Mayhem: Images From Year 3 of the War in Ukraine
desc: A photographic chronicle of the third year of Russia’s invasion.
author: NA

header: Israel’s foreign minister thanks the Senate for passing a hard-fought aid bill.
desc: NA
author: By Matt Surman

header: A U.S. aid package includes billions in military support for Israel.
desc: NA
author: By Anushka Patil

header: After $15 Billion in Military Aid, Israel Calls Alliance With U.S. ‘Ironclad’
desc: The money from Washington, which includes $5 billion to replenish Israel’s defenses and $1 billion for Gazan civilians, comes as Israel readies to invade Rafah.

header: Ukraine Is Denying Consular Services to Men Outside the Country

header: Putin’s War Will Soon Reach Russians’ Tax Bills

desc: As they return with physical and psychological wounds stemming from torture by their Russian captors, soldiers are being sent back to active duty — often without adequate treatment.

header: Ukraine Retreats From Villages on Eastern Front as It Awaits U.S. Aid

header: Israeli Officials Believe International Court Is Preparing Arrest Warrants Over War

desc: Plus, European countries crack down on China’s influence.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Deadly Russian Strikes Hit Civilian Center and Other Targets in Odesa

header: Bulgarian Distrust of Russia Simmers Over a Black Sea Oil Terminal
desc: Russia has been losing its grip on the Rosenets Oil Terminal, near the port city of Burgas, as Bulgarian authorities seek to assert greater control over the Russian-run facility.

desc: Opponents of the measure, which resembles a Russian law that Moscow has used to crack down on dissidents, say it could undermine efforts for Georgia to join the European Union.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Hamas and Fatah Officials, Longtime Rivals, Met in China
desc: The Chinese government did not say when the talks between the main Palestinian factions were held. Expectations for progress were low.
author: By Damien Cave and Adam Rasgon

header: Wednesday Briefing: Clashes Escalate on U.S. Campuses
desc: Also, a judge fined Donald Trump for breaking a gag order.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: U.S. Accuses Russia of Using Chemical Weapons in Ukraine
desc: The State Department said Russia had used chloropicrin, a poison gas widely used during World War I, against Ukrainian forces, an act that would violate a global ban signed by Moscow.

header: Drones Changed This Civil War, and Linked Rebels to the World

header: Friday Briefing: Hamas Considers Israel’s Proposal
desc: Also, the U.S. accused Russia of using chemical weapons.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: DNA Tests and Stranded Bodies: Ukraine’s Struggle to Name Its Dead
desc: Families of some soldiers say they have spent months trying to get official confirmation of their loved ones’ deaths, adding to their anguish.

header: Family Values or Fighting Valor? Russia Grapples With Women’s Wartime Role.

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ekaterina Bodyagina

header: Xi Visits Europe, Seeking Strategic Opportunity
desc: The Chinese leader has carefully chosen three countries — France, Serbia and Hungary — that to varying degrees embrace Beijing’s push for a new global order.
author: By Roger Cohen and Chris Buckley

header: Just How Dangerous Is Europe’s Rising Far Right?
desc: Anti-immigration parties with fascist roots — and an uncertain commitment to democracy — are now mainstream.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Monday Briefing: Xi Jinping Visits Europe
desc: Also, Israel cracks down on Al Jazeera and Myanmar’s rebels get creative with drones.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Russia to Hold Drills on Tactical Nuclear Weapons in New Tensions With West
desc: Russian officials claimed the order was in response to comments from the West about the possibility of more direct involvement in Ukraine. NATO called Russia’s announcement “irresponsible.”

header: Ukraine Says It Foiled Russian Plot to Kill Zelensky
desc: The Ukrainian security services arrested two Ukrainian colonels and accused them of spying for Russia. They said the plot also targeted top Ukrainian intelligence officials.
author: By Constant Méheut and Maria Varenikova

desc: Talks in Paris with President Macron produced a call for an “Olympics truce” this summer but no concrete progress on Beijing putting pressure on Russia.

desc: The event for the Russian president, who claimed his fifth term in a rubber-stamp election, included a church service that underscored efforts to give a religious sheen to his rule.

header: Tuesday Briefing
desc: Israel’s strikes on Rafah.
author: By Natasha Frost

header: What to Know About Xi Jinping’s Trip to Europe

desc: The American soldier was detained last week. He was traveling home after being stationed in South Korea, according to the U.S. authorities.

header: Britain to Expel Russian Defense Attaché and Close Some Diplomatic Sites

header: Ukraine’s Parliament Passes Bill Allowing Some Convicts to Serve in the Army

header: In Budapest, Xi Hails a ‘Deep Friendship’ With Hungary

header: Fico campaigned on ending support for Ukraine, alarming many in the West.
desc: NA

desc: Ukraine said it was slowing Russia’s push near Kharkiv, where the president met with top commanders, but still faced pitched battles in that area and farther south.

desc: Russia also warned of further action, while the British foreign secretary called the expulsion a “desperate move.”

desc: At a summit with China’s leader, in Beijing, the Russian president called for stronger economic ties between the countries, as he intensifies his war effort.

header: Slovakia’s Politics Were Toxic Long Before Its Prime Minister Was Shot
desc: Years of vitriolic rhetoric, worsened by the Covid-19 pandemic and the war in Ukraine, left Slovakia with bitter political division.

header: Slovak officials call the shooting suspect a ‘lone wolf’ who had recently been radicalized.
desc: NA
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

desc: The Ukrainian boxer Oleksandr Usyk became the world’s undisputed heavyweight champion on Sunday. The victory has lifted morale in a country struggling to contain Russian advances on the battlefield.

header: The Technocrat Who’s Taking Control of Putin’s War Effort
desc: Andrei R. Belousov, an intellectual with no military experience, is known for backing a state-dominated economy.

header: Xi’s Warm Embrace of Putin in China Is a Defiance of the West

header: Crash Comes as Iran and the U.S. Are Working Through Several Conflicts
desc: The two countries are groping their way out of a number of simultaneous crises, including over the Islamic Republic’s nuclear program.

header: Georgia’s President Vetoes Foreign Influence Law
desc: The law has triggered protests and threatens to derail the nation’s pro-European aspirations in favor of closer ties with Russia.

header: Russian Forces Close In on Ukrainian Town in Northeast
desc: Vovchansk has been a prime target of Russia’s offensive in the northeast as it seeks to push back Ukrainian troops from the border.

desc: The government has for the first time ordered nationwide rolling blackouts for Monday night to conserve energy.

header: ‘What’s the Problem?’ Zelensky Challenges West Over Hesitations.

header: Forced to Relive Childhood Horrors in Old Age
desc: The oldest Ukrainians whose towns have been bombarded and overrun by Russia’s invasion have memories of similar miseries at the hands of Nazi Germany in World War II.

header: Zelensky Says ‘Escalation Has Already Occurred’ in Ukraine War
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine suggested that Western allies were hesitant to take bolder steps to aid his country in part because they wanted to maintain trade and diplomatic ties with Russia.
author: By Daniel Bateman For The New York Times and Phil Caller For The New York Times

header: Evacuation Point
desc: As they evacuated from the fighting in Ukraine, the passengers already thought of what they left behind.
author: By Emile Ducke

header: Under Relentless Russian Assault, Ukraine Adopts a Defensive Crouch
desc: As Moscow’s forces retake land from which they were ousted at the end of 2022, the Ukrainian military has adopted a strategy of fighting while slowly falling back to more heavily fortified positions.

desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that he needed “weapons and permission” to better defend his country.
author: By Daniel Bateman For The New York Times and Phil Caller For The New York Times

header: NATO’s Reluctance to Shoot Down Russian Missiles Frustrates Zelensky
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged NATO allies to play an active role in the war, saying it was a matter of defense.
author: By Daniel Bateman For The New York Times and Phil Caller For The New York Times

header: Russia Starts Tactical Nuclear Drills, in a Warning to Ukraine’s Allies
desc: Moscow has said the exercise is a response to “provocative statements and threats of individual Western officials.”
author: By Paul Sonne

header: Advancing Russian Troops Threaten to Reverse Some of Ukraine’s Hard-Won Gains
desc: Such losses could hurt Ukrainian morale as Russia makes advances all along the front line.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Russia Detains Another Defense Official, in New Sign of Putin Shake-Up
desc: Lt. Gen. Vadim Shamarin is accused of “large-scale” bribery, the latest in a series of high-profile arrests that have coincided with the appointment of a new defense minister.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Friday Briefing: Aid Trickles Through Gaza Pier
desc: Also, China holds ‘punishment’ drills around Taiwan.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Ukraine Steps Up Attacks With U.S. Long-Range Missiles
desc: The assaults have hit military targets in Russian-occupied territory in Ukraine. Pressure is now mounting on Washington to let Kyiv fire the missiles into Russia itself.

header: Russia Bombs Hardware Superstore in Kharkiv, Killing 12, Ukraine Says
desc: It was the latest attack in a sustained bombing campaign that has made life increasingly dangerous for civilians in the northeastern Ukrainian city.
author: By Constant Méheut

desc: Two classified Ukrainian reports show that some U.S. precision-guided weapons are vulnerable to electronic warfare, an element in Ukraine’s recent battlefield setbacks.

header: Ukraine Starts Freeing Some Prisoners to Join Its Military
desc: Nearly 350 inmates have been freed under a new law that allows them to serve in exchange for the possibility of parole, the country’s justice minister said.

desc: Despite years of criticism, President Vladimir V. Putin has only now changed his defense minister and allowed high-level corruption arrests.
