header: Russia Plans New Offensive in Ukraine’s Northeast, Zelensky Says
desc: Moscow is again amassing forces near the border, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine warned. His comments came as officials said that a Russian strike had killed at least 16 people in Kharkiv.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: U.S. Lawmakers Visit Taiwan and Vow Support in Face of Chinese Military Drills
desc: A bipartisan delegation promised to stand by the island’s newly elected president, Lai Ching-te, after Beijing surrounded the self-governing island with naval vessels and aircraft.
author: By Catie Edmondson

header: North Korean Rocket Carrying Spy Satellite Explodes After Takeoff
desc: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, has made deploying a fleet of spy satellites one of his country’s latest <U+200B>military ambitions.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun

header: China, Japan and South Korea Hold Regional Summit Overshadowed by U.S.
desc: In the first trilateral meeting since 2019, the neighbors sought common ground in trade and cultural exchange while tiptoeing around thorny security issues.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun

header: A Border Runs Through Their Families. Now It’s a Front Line.
desc: In northeastern Ukraine, and in the part of Russia it touches, the war strains the emotions of people with relatives, and family histories, that span both sides.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Calls Mount to Let Ukraine Strike Russia With Western Weapons
desc: The U.S. and other allies have banned Ukraine from firing Western weapons into Russia. Kyiv says that has handcuffed its ability to prevent cross-border attacks.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Blinken Hints U.S. May Accept Ukrainian Strikes in Russia With American Arms
desc: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken made his remarks after some European leaders called on President Biden to lift the restrictions he has imposed on Ukraine’s use of U.S. weapons.
author: By Edward Wong

header: Divisions Set to Deepen in Georgia After Foreign Influence Law Passes
desc: Many Georgians see restrictions on organizations that receive international funding as a sign their country is moving away from the West and toward a Russia they abhor.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: What the I.C.J. Ruling Actually Means for Israel’s Offensive in Rafah
desc: There is a substantial consensus among legal experts that Israel cannot continue its current Rafah offensive without violating the court’s order.
author: By Amanda Taub

header: Three European Countries Formally Recognize Palestinian Statehood
desc: The moves are a rebuke to Israel, who is the face of mounting international anger over the country’s military offensive in Gaza.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Georgia’s Ruling Party Secures a Contentious Law on Foreign Influence
desc: The Parliament, controlled by the Georgian Dream party, overrode a presidential veto of a bill critics say could undermine the country’s efforts to join the European Union.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Ukraine Warns of Deepening Russian Threat in the North
desc: Analysts say an offensive in the Kharkiv or Sumy regions could stretch Ukrainian troops to the breaking point and allow Moscow to punch through.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Ukrainian Drone Strikes Target Russian Nuclear Radar Stations
desc: A radar facility more than 1,100 miles into Russia was damaged, satellite imagery showed. The attacks have drawn concern from U.S. officials.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Blinken Hints U.S. May Allow Ukraine Greater Latitude to Strike in Russia
desc: The U.S. secretary of state suggested that Ukraine’s use of American-supplied arms could expand beyond the current limitation to strikes in the Kharkiv area.
author: By Edward Wong

header: On Northern Border, Permission to Fire Into Russia Buoys Ukraine
desc: After weeks of entreaties, Ukraine won permission to hit targets inside Russia with American-made weapons, a tactic that it says will help it defend territory in the northeast.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: The Weapons That Ukraine Might Use to Shoot Into Russia
desc: Decisions by President Biden and others give Ukrainian forces several new options. But they’re still restricted in the use of Western missiles that could strike far inside Russia.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Taking the Fight to Russia: The West Weighs Ukraine’s Use of Its Weapons
desc: More NATO allies are backing Kyiv’s pleas to allow its forces to conduct strikes in Russian territory with Western weapons.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: U.S. Defense Chief Says Asia-Pacific Region Remains Priority
desc: Speaking in Singapore, Lloyd J. Austin III sought to reassure allies and put China on notice that Ukraine and the Mideast were not distracting the U.S. from this focus.
author: By Chris Buckley and Damien Cave

header: After Trump’s Conviction, a Wary World Waits for the Fallout
desc: Already braced for uncertainty about the U.S. election, countries in Europe and Asia are now even more unclear about the future of American diplomacy.
author: By Hannah Beech and Paul Sonne

header: Russian Missiles Hit Ukraine’s Energy System, Again
desc: The large-scale air assault struck several sites in western Ukraine, including places near the borders with NATO member countries.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: She’s 98, and Walked Past Corpses to Escape Russian Attacks
desc: “If only everything would stop,” said Lidiia Lomikovska, who walked to safety after her town was attacked. But for civilians in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, it is not stopping.
author: By Marc Santora, Liubov Sholudko and Tyler Hicks

header: 46 Children Were Taken From Ukraine. Many Are Up for Adoption in Russia.
desc: The New York Times traced how a web of officials and politicians aligned with President Vladimir V. Putin’s party carried out a campaign to permanently transfer Ukrainian children from Kherson.
author: By Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak

header: How We Found 46 Ukrainian Children Taken by Russian Officials
desc: The New York Times traced how a web of politicians aligned with President Vladimir Putin’s party carried out a campaign to permanently transfer Ukrainian children from Kherson.
author: By Nikolay Nikolov, Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak and Natalie Reneau

header: A Surging Hard Right in Europe Stumbles Over Its Own Divisions
desc: Elections starting this week for the European Parliament could leave far-right parties with more power than ever, but also expose the fissures among them.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: In Singapore, China Warns U.S. While Zelensky Seeks Support
desc: The annual Shangri-La Dialogue became a stage for competing demands on U.S. global power, including the war in Ukraine and tensions over Taiwan.
author: By Chris Buckley and Damien Cave

header: As Challenges Pile Up, a Spate of Summitry Spotlights Western Resolve
desc: Wars in Ukraine and Gaza, along with Donald J. Trump’s candidacy, are testing the Western alliance. But starting with the 80th anniversary of D-Day this week, leaders have a rare opportunity to showcase unity.
author: By Mark Landler

header: The Internet’s Final Frontier: Remote Amazon Tribes
desc: Elon Musk’s Starlink has connected an isolated tribe to the outside world — and divided it from within.
author: By Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama

header: Monday Briefing: What’s Next for South Africa
desc: Also, India’s elections and internet in the Amazon.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Ukraine Strikes Into Russia With Western Weapons, Official Says
desc: The official said Ukraine had destroyed missile launchers in the Russian region of Belgorod using an American-made rocket system.
author: By Maria Varenikova, Constant Méheut and Aric Toler

header: What Ukraine Has Lost
desc: We measured every town, street and building blown apart in Ukraine to show the first comprehensive picture of where people can’t return home.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Finbarr O’Reilly, Tim Wallace and Marco Hernandez

header: How We Tracked Every Damaged or Destroyed Building in Ukraine
desc: This is the first comprehensive map showing the destruction of the war in Ukraine. Using detailed analysis of years of satellite data, it shows every building that has been damaged or destroyed since Russia attacked in 2022.
author: By Marco Hernandez and Nikolay Nikolov

header: In Former Soviet States, a Tug of War Between East and West
desc: Geopolitical rivalry, intensified by fighting in Ukraine, is amplifying domestic struggles in countries like Georgia and Moldova whose people are split on which side to support.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Wednesday Briefing: Modi’s Bruising Path to a Third Term
desc: Also, a Times analysis of the destruction in Ukraine.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: As Ukraine’s Summer Starts With Blackouts, Worries Over Winter Begin
desc: Recent rolling power outages have raised alarm about what will happen when cold weather arrives and energy consumption goes even higher.
author: By Constant Méheut and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn

header: Between the Offensives: Images From a Journey in Ukraine’s Borderland
desc: Photographs from two trips along Ukraine’s northeastern border regions, in the months before Russia renewed an offensive there, reveal loss and transformation.
author: By David Guttenfelder and Peter Robins

header: Bombed and Bruised, a City Braces for Another Russian Onslaught
desc: Residents of Sumy, in northeastern Ukraine, repelled Moscow’s forces in 2022. Now, after months of punishing airstrikes, Ukrainian officials say the Kremlin is preparing a new offensive.
author: By Carlotta Gall and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Biden Links Fight for Ukraine With Allied Effort on D-Day
desc: Speaking in Normandy, the president argued that similar principles were at stake in both wars: the defense of freedom and a rules-based international order.
author: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

header: Zelensky Shares Emotional Moment With U.S. Veteran at D-Day Ceremony
desc: The veteran, Melvin Hurwitz, embraced the Ukrainian president and called him “the savior of the people.” Mr. Zelensky told Mr. Hurwitz that he and his fellow World War II veterans had “saved Europe.”
author: By Orlando Mayorquín

header: Russia Detains a French National Suspected of Collecting Military Data
desc: The detention is the latest in a series in which foreigners have been arrested or held against their will in Russia, exacerbating tensions with the West.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The E.U. Is Voting. It’s Never Mattered More.
desc: Hundreds of millions of voters are electing a European Parliament this weekend. The outcome will help tip the balance of the continent’s struggle between unity and nationalism.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: D-Day at 80
desc: Veterans of the pivotal battle of World War II are disappearing. Europe, facing new conflict, recalls what their comrades died for.
author: By Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon

header: A Russian American Is Sentenced in Russia Over Social Media Posts
desc: The latest detention of an American national in Russia has renewed fears that the Kremlin is seeking to use U.S. citizens as bargaining chips.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Alina Lobzina

header: Slovak Prime Minister Speaks Publicly for First Time Since Assassination Attempt
desc: Robert Fico said in a video address that he hoped to return to work in the coming weeks. He blamed the political opposition for the attack, a notion that the parties have strongly denied.
author: By Jesus Jiménez and Sara Cincurova

header: Energy Drinks Boost Ukraine’s Soldiers, and Its Economy
desc: Cans packed with caffeine and branded with patriotic machismo have become an essential antidote to the stresses of war.
author: By Jeffrey Gettleman

header: Biden Straddles the Patriotic and the Political in Speech at Normandy
desc: The president said “echoes of 1944 are summoning us” during his address that honored the valor of D-Day fighters.
author: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear

header: As Fighting Rages in Ukraine, a Struggle Is On for Artillery Supremacy
desc: Ukrainian forces say U.S. shells are making a difference. Across the border, they say, Russia is trying to get its artillery nearer targets like the city of Kharkiv.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Macron Hosts Biden in Paris, Honoring a Not Always Easy Bond
desc: The friendship between France and the U.S. endures. But tensions have mounted over the wars in Gaza and Ukraine, and how Europe can step out of America’s shadow.
author: By Roger Cohen and Peter Baker

header: Biden and Macron Talk Togetherness, With No Mention of Discord Over Gaza
desc: The two presidents, in a brief appearance before reporters, declined to take questions, in a departure from tradition.
author: By Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker

header: French-American Friendship in Four Courses
desc: Under Emmanuel Macron, “culinary diplomacy” is back on the menu, with a lavish dinner fortifying an old alliance at a tense historical moment.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: The E.U. Votes: What We’re Watching For
desc: The main things to know as voters in 27 countries head to the ballot box to shape the next five years of European Union policies.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Sarah Hurtes

header: Jordan Bardella, the New Face of France’s Surging Right
desc: Charismatic and clean cut, shorn of the Le Pen name, the young National Rally leader took his party to its blockbuster showing in European elections on Sunday.
author: By Roger Cohen

header: British Leader Apologizes for Leaving D-Day Commemoration Early
desc: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak conceded that he made a major public relations misstep in the heat of a general election campaign.
author: By Mark Landler

header: Their City Has a Plaque From Putin. They Want Zelensky to Tear It Down.
desc: Some residents of Bari, Italy, hope Ukraine’s president will drop by while at a nearby summit to help rid them of a memento of links with Russia.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Reconstruction Official Resigns, Highlighting Tensions in Ukraine
desc: The departure of the official, who had pointed up mismanagement of funds, was a blow to government efforts to assuage allies’ concerns about how aid is spent.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russia Releases Female Prison Inmates to Join Ukraine War
desc: Tens of thousands of male convicts have been freed to fight in Ukraine. It is not clear if a small contingent of female volunteers released from a prison portends wider use of female soldiers.
author: By Ekaterina Bodyagina and Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Ukrainian Activist Traces Roots of War in ‘Centuries of Russian Colonization’
desc: One Ukrainian researcher and podcaster is a leading voice in efforts to rethink Ukrainian-Russian relations through the prism of colonialism.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Sunny Days in Moscow
desc: A single image of a blustery day in wartime Moscow captures the feeling of triumph sweeping through Russia.
author: By Nanna Heitmann

header: Buoyed by Election, Meloni Basks in Spotlight as Italy Hosts G7
desc: The Italian prime minister was a rare leader to be fortified by the vote for the European Parliament. This week she has a chance to show her influence on an even broader stage.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: Battered by Far Right in E.U. Vote, Macron Calls for New Elections in France
desc: The president’s decision, on the eve of the summer Olympic Games that begin in Paris in July, ushered in a period of deep political uncertainty in France.
author: By Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden

header: In E.U. Elections, the Center Holds, but the Far Right Still Wreaks Havoc
desc: Voters in the European Union delivered strong gains to anti-immigrant, nationalist parties, challenging leaders in Germany and France, and unsettling the political establishment.
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: Iran Names Six Candidates for President, Including Parliament Speaker
desc: The June 28 election to succeed President Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash last month, comes as the country faces acute domestic and international challenges.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: In Calling Elections in France, Macron Makes a Huge Gamble
desc: The president has challenged voters to test the sincerity of their support for the far right in European elections. Were the French letting off steam, or did they really mean it?
author: By Roger Cohen

header: Every Dollar Counts. To Pay for the War, Ukraine Embraces Privatization
desc: The government hopes to sell off a range of companies to fund the military and stabilize the economy as the grueling conflict with Russia drains its coffers.
author: By Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk

header: Ukraine Says It Shot Down Most of a Russian Missile and Drone Barrage
desc: Drawing on replenished supplies, Ukraine used mostly Western-provided air defense systems to deter the overnight assault.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer

header: Russian Warships Enter Havana Harbor as Part of Planned Exercises
desc: Experts called the naval exercises routine but also a show of strength as Washington maintains military support for Ukraine in its war against Russia.
author: By Eve Sampson

header: Weakened Leaders of the West Gather in Italy to Discuss an Unruly World
desc: The Group of 7 gathers major industrialized countries, but its leaders are politically weak and Ukraine and Gaza remain unsolved.
author: By Mark Landler and Steven Erlanger

header: In Wake of Election Defeat, Germany’s Weakened Leader Will Slog On
desc: Chancellor Olaf Scholz and his governing coalition emerged battered from the vote for the European Parliament. But a snap election seems unlikely.
author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Sarah Maslin Nir

header: Christophe Deloire, Who Fought for Threatened Journalists, Dies at 53
desc: As the leader and spokesman for Reporters Without Borders, he rescued some, sought refuge for others and lobbied for pluralism in the press.
author: By Sam Roberts

header: Pope Francis Is Accused of Using a Homophobic Slur Again
desc: Two prominent Italian news agencies said the pontiff used the term on Tuesday during a meeting with priests, after he was accused of uttering the same word last month while speaking with Italian bishops.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: In China’s Backyard, America Has Become a Humbler Superpower
desc: The United States no longer towers over the Asia-Pacific, dictating terms to its allies. Instead, it’s offering to be a teammate and share responsibilities.
author: By Damien Cave

header: Saudi Arabia’s Next Billion-Dollar Sports Play: A Boxing Takeover
desc: A proposal awaiting financing would attempt to bring together dozens of the world’s best boxers in a single, Saudi-run pro league.
author: By Tariq Panja

header: Wednesday Briefing: Hunter Biden Found Guilty on Gun Charges
desc: Also, pressure on Israel and Hamas to reach a deal.
author: By Amelia Nierenberg

header: Ukraine Welcomes Pledges of More Military Aid With Cautious Optimism
desc: Kyiv signed security pacts with several Western allies this week. Whether they will fundamentally change the course of the war, or endure beyond looming elections elsewhere, is unclear.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Japan Commits $4.5 Billion for Ukraine, Zelensky Says
desc: The agreement underscores Japan’s efforts to strengthen its security and diplomatic ties with Europe after the full-scale conflict began in 2022.
author: By Tim Balk

header: Ukraine Stalled Russia Near the Border. This Town Has Paid the Price.
desc: Faced with an assault from the northeast, Ukrainian forces made their stand in Vovchansk. The front line is still there, but little else is.
author: By Finbarr O’Reilly and Maria Varenikova

header: Putin Makes Cease-Fire Offer With Sweeping Demands on Ukraine’s Territory
desc: Ukraine denounced the offer, saying that Mr. Putin was “afraid of real peace.” The Russian leader made the remarks one day before a peace summit organized by Kyiv.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Paul Sonne

header: G7 Leaders Agree on $50 Billion Loan to Ukraine From Frozen Russian Assets
desc: The agreement comes as Ukraine has been forced to sell some state assets and as the momentum in the war has shifted in favor of Russia.
author: By Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger

header: G7 Agrees to $50 Billion Ukraine Loan Backed by Russian Assets. How Will It Work?
desc: The United States and others plan to give the sum to Kyiv, with the interest from Moscow’s assets frozen in the West used to repay it. But many of the details about the arrangement are unclear.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: A U.S. pact aims to help Ukraine’s military into the future, officials say.
desc: The deal will outline a long-term effort to train and equip Ukraine’s forces, promising to provide more modern weapons and help the Ukrainians build their own self-sustaining military industry that is capable of producing its own arms, U.S. officials said.
author: By David E. Sanger

header: Will Biden’s Help for Ukraine Come Fast Enough and Last Long Enough?
desc: The president signed a 10-year security pact with Ukraine and promised, with E.U. help, a $50 billion loan. But will the money arrive in time to turn the tide, and will the deal outlast the election in November?
author: By David E. Sanger

header: At a meeting of a Ukraine defense alliance, Austin pledges to keep sending military aid.
desc: NA
author: By John Ismay

header: G7 Leaders, Expanding the Circle, Shift Focus to Migration and the South
desc: Leaders from India, Brazil, the Middle East and Africa joined discussions in a nod to the changing global balance of power.
author: By Mark Landler and Steven Erlanger

header: Inside the Chechen Units Helping to Fight Russia’s War
desc: After hundreds of years of enmity with Russia, Chechens are deploying to Ukraine to fight Moscow’s war.
author: By Nanna Heitmann and Neil MacFarquhar

header: The Sticking Points That Kept Russia and Ukraine Apart
desc: Documents from 2022 shed new light on what prevented Ukraine and Russia from ending the war — and what would complicate a future negotiation.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Michael Schwirtz

header: Ukraine-Russia Peace Is as Elusive as Ever. But in 2022 They Were Talking.
desc: Representatives from the warring nations held peace talks in the early weeks of the Russian invasion. They fizzled. Documents from those talks show why any new ones will face major obstacles.
author: By Anton Troianovski, Adam Entous and Michael Schwirtz

header: More Than 80 Nations Back Talks to Ease Path to Peace in Ukraine
desc: Meeting in Switzerland, world leaders backed a joint statement urging more diplomacy, but were divided on how to engage Russia.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Ukraine Peace Talks Held in Switzerland, Though Russia Isn’t Invited
desc: Kyiv hopes to garner nations’ support for three points in its peace proposal, but it’s a hard sell, with China and Brazil declining to send high-level delegations.
author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Anton Troianovski and Andrew E. Kramer

header: Western Anxiety Makes for an Unexpectedly Smooth G7 Summit
desc: Political weakness, intractable wars in Ukraine and in the Middle East, and challenges from Russia and China combined to create solidarity behind American leadership.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: Russian Forces Quash Prison Mutiny Led by Terrorism Suspects, State Media Reports
desc: The assailants had taken two guards hostage and were killed, the prison service said.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: It’s Not Just Russia: China Joins the G7’s List of Adversaries
desc: While not invited to the Group of 7 meeting, China was still a major presence, with the summit’s final communiqué referencing the country 28 times, almost always as a malign force.
author: By David E. Sanger

header: America’s Voice in Taiwan Has Some Parting Advice About China
desc: Worries about Chinese belligerence rose during Sandra Oudkirk’s three years in Taipei. As she leaves, she is seeking to assure Taiwan of continued U.S. support.
author: By Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien

header: The Greens Are Dead. Long Live the Greens!
desc: Europe’s climate change-minded parties performed poorly in the European Union elections. Is the once ambitious European green movement over, or could its electoral crash launch a rebirth?
author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff

header: A Battlefield Break to Cheer Ukraine’s Soccer Team in Euro 2024
desc: Soldiers huddled in a bunker with soft drinks and chips to watch Ukraine face Romania, only to suffer heartbreak.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn

header: ‘A Big Step Back’: In Ukraine, Concerns Mount Over Narrowing Press Freedoms
desc: Journalists say they are subject to increasing restrictions and pressure from the government of President Volodymyr Zelensky, adding that the measures go beyond wartime security needs.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Constant Méheut

header: Putin Arrives in North Korea as Ukraine War Redefines Ties With Kim
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin’s military needs have prompted the Kremlin to strengthen ties with the authoritarian government of Kim Jong-un, which is well stocked in munitions.
author: By Paul Sonne

header: What Weapons Is North Korea Accused of Supplying to Russia?
desc: Moscow needs conventional arms like artillery shells and missiles that North Korea could provide to give it an edge in its war of attrition in Ukraine.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Blast Shelters and Radar Jamming: A Russian City Adapts to War
desc: While in Moscow the fighting feels far away, residents of Belgorod, 25 miles from the border with Ukraine, have learned to duck for cover when the sirens wail.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Putin and Kim Sign Pact Pledging Mutual Support Against ‘Aggression’
desc: A need for munitions to use against Ukraine is pushing Russia’s leader to deepen his ties with North Korea, raising alarms in the West. The text of the agreement was not immediately released.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun and Paul Sonne

header: In Need of Munitions, Putin to Visit North Korea
desc: <U+200B>Seeking more weapons for the war in Ukraine, the Russian president plans to return to the country on Tuesday for the first time in nearly a quarter-century.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun

header: Russia Sets Date for Start of Evan Gershkovich’s Trial
desc: The announcement of a hearing next week is the most significant movement in the Wall Street Journal reporter’s case since his arrest in March 2023 on espionage charges.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Who Owns Alexander the Great? It’s a Diplomatic Minefield.
desc: North Macedonia has claimed historical figures as part of a drive to build a national identity. That has ruffled the feathers of the Balkan nation’s neighbors.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Emerging From Orban’s Shadow, a Former Ally Tries to Steal His Limelight
desc: Peter Magyar, a conservative who was once a well-connected figure in the Fidesz party of Prime Minister Viktor Orban, has become an unexpected leader of the country’s opposition.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: How Two Beluga Whales Made It to Safety From Ukraine
desc: A pair of whales were extricated from the besieged city of Kharkiv and taken to an aquarium in Spain with help from experts around the world.
author: By Marc Santora and Emily Anthes

header: Putin Threatens to Arm North Korea, Escalating Tension With West Over Ukraine
desc: The Russian leader issued the warning at the end of a trip to Asia, during which he signed a mutual defense pact with North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un.
author: By Paul Sonne

header: Clearing a Final Hurdle, Dutch Leader Is Poised to Become NATO Chief
desc: Mark Rutte, the Netherlands’ prime minister, is expected to be elected as the head of the military alliance after Romania’s candidate dropped out.
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Putin’s Presidential Planes: What We Know
desc: The Kremlin clings to Soviet-designed aircraft even as Russia’s commercial carriers opt for Western planes.
author: By Eve Sampson

header: Asian Fears Come True as North Korea’s Russia Pact Amplifies Threat
desc: While the agreement rattled officials in South Korea and Japan, the two U.S. allies in recent years have been expecting growing security challenges from North Korea.
author: By Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun

header: 3 Takeaways From Putin’s Trip to Vietnam
desc: The state visit by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to Vietnam had a very different backdrop than his trip to North Korea, as Hanoi has deepened ties with Washington.
author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Paul Sonne

header: Why Is Putin in Vietnam?
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin is keen to maintain the longstanding military ties between Russia and Vietnam, as Hanoi has developed deeper bonds with Washington.
author: By Sui-Lee Wee

header: Russia and North Korea’s Defense Pact Is a New Headache for China
desc: The treaty raises the risk of confrontation in the region and could prompt the United States and its allies to bolster their military presence on China’s periphery.
author: By David Pierson and Choe Sang-Hun

header: Russia Sentences U.S. Soldier to 4 Years in Prison
desc: Staff Sgt. Gordon Black was accused of making death threats against, and stealing money from, a woman with whom he was romantically involved.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Why Darfur Again Faces the Risk of Ethnic Slaughter
desc: Satellite and video evidence shows that thousands of homes have been razed and tens of thousands of people forced to flee a city in Sudan.
author: By The New York Times

header: As Ukraine Expands Military Draft, Some Men Go Into Hiding
desc: Fearful that conscription is a one-way ticket to bloody trench warfare, the men spend their days holed up at home to avoid draft officers who roam the streets.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Putin Shows He Can Antagonize the U.S. Far Afield From Ukraine
desc: His support for North Korea’s military ambitions showed he can inflict pain on the U.S. and its NATO allies in ways beyond aggression in Ukraine.
author: By Paul Sonne

header: Putin Came to Asia to Disrupt, and He Succeeded
desc: His embrace of North Korea and deal making with Vietnam injected more potential threats into a region already strained by Taiwan tensions and South China Sea clashes.
author: By Damien Cave

header: Finally, a Euros for a Whole Continent
desc: Eastern European countries who have in recent years lagged behind their continent’s bigger names are having their day in the sun in Germany.
author: By Rory Smith

header: Ukraine Urges Allies to Allow Their Weapons to Target Russian Air Power
desc: After bombs again rained on Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-biggest city, President Volodymyr Zelensky asked Western partners to permit the use of their weapons against air bases inside Russia.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Zelensky Removes a Top General Amid Criticism of Excessive Casualties
desc: The announcement by Ukraine’s president on Monday came hours after a scathing social media post implicitly accused the general of “killing more Ukrainian soldiers than any Russian general.”
author: By Marc Santora

header: Deadly Attack Revives Fears of the Return of Mass Terror in Russia
desc: A deadly assault in the southern region of Dagestan has put a spotlight on the failing of Russian security services amid the war in Ukraine.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: 2 Russian Women Put on a Play. Then the State Came for Them.
desc: The prosecution of a prominent playwright and a director in Russia over their work is a chilling sign of increased repression, cultural figures say.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: France’s Far-Right Leader Says the National Rally Is Ready to Govern
desc: If he becomes prime minister after snap elections, Jordan Bardella, the party’s president, said he would represent all. But he also said dual citizens should not hold some “sensitive” jobs.
author: By Aurelien Breeden

header: Gunmen Attack Synagogues and Churches in Russian Republic
desc: Multiple law-enforcement officers and a priest in the region of Dagestan were killed in what appeared to be coordinated attacks, local officials said.
author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Attacks in Russia’s Dagestan Region: What to Know
desc: Gunmen killed at least 20 people in attacks in two Dagestan cities. No suspects or motives have been identified, but the region has long been rocked by ethnic and religious violence.
author: By Eve Sampson

header: Monday Briefing: Among Some Israelis, Muted Sympathy for Gaza
desc: Also, shootings in Dagestan, a Russian republic.

author: By Natasha Frost

desc: NA

header: Aleksei Navalny’s widow says the release of political prisoners is a ‘huge victory.’
desc: NA

desc: Evan Gershkovich was raised in New Jersey by parents who left the Soviet Union to escape antisemitism and a lack of opportunity.

header: Germany released a prisoner who was particularly crucial to the swap.
desc: NA

header: Two Russians released by Slovenia had acted as undercover spies.
desc: NA
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Russian emissary visits Tehran at a tense moment as Iran asks for military aid.
desc: NA
author: By Farnaz Fassihi

header: Iran criticizes European leaders who urged restraint, and other news.
desc: NA
author: NA

desc: The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, will raise thorny issues like Taiwan and Russia with only months left before a new administration takes office.

desc: The Russian president is making a state visit to a country that is heavily dependent on Moscow for oil.

header: Missile and Drone Attacks Across Ukraine Kill at Least 7 in Lviv
desc: Russia attacked a number of cities a day after a devastating strike in the country’s east, Ukrainian officials said.

header: Russia’s Attack on Poltava Comes After a Week of Strikes in Ukraine

header: Ukraine’s Top Diplomat Has Become a Familiar Face, Rallying Wartime Support

header: Ukraine’s foreign minister offers to resign as Zelensky plans major shake-up.
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky is expected to make the broadest changes to his government since Russia invaded more than two years ago.

header: Ukraine Names Candidates for Its New Cabinet in Major Overhaul
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky said that he was acting to bring a “new energy” to state institutions at an important diplomatic juncture.

header: Meeting With Allies, Zelensky Presses for More Weapons

header: An I.C.C. arrest warrant limits Putin’s movements. This is how he handles it.
desc: NA

desc: NA

desc: NA

desc: Viktoria Roshchyna died in September in Russian custody. The reporter had been well-known for her stories about life in parts of occupied Ukraine.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: How Will Ukraine Keep the Lights on This Winter?
desc: The Ukrainian energy network has been so battered by Russian attacks that officials are seeking out new options to prevent a crisis, like renting floating power plants and scavenging scrapped ones from the region.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: At 23, Surviving Scandal to Take a Green Seat in the E.U. Parliament
desc: Lena Schilling, the youngest lawmaker in Brussels, faced a harsh questioning of her character and credibility before winning a chance to fight against climate change in the halls of power.
author: By Valeriya Safronova

header: A Cultural Casualty of the War in Ukraine: ‘The Nutcracker’
desc: Lithuania’s national opera house had stopped showing Tchaikovsky’s 1892 masterpiece in solidarity with Ukraine over the war with Russia. Then a new minister expressed fondness for the Russian composer, igniting a furor.
author: By Andrew Higgins and Jenny Gross

header: Why Are North Korean Troops in Ukraine Taking Heavy Casualties?
desc: The North Korean army is one of the world’s largest.<U+200B> As it joins Russia’s war against Ukraine, its soldiers are paying a price for Kim Jong-un’s geopolitical maneuvers.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun

header: Slovak Leader Visits Putin, Breaking With E.U.’s Policy of Isolation
desc: Prime Minister Robert Fico’s surprise visit to Moscow on Sunday, reportedly to discuss natural gas and Ukraine, was a blow to European unity against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: A Canceled Vote in Romania Hands Russia a Propaganda Coup
desc: Many in the West have applauded the annulling of the first round of the presidential election, won by a Moscow-friendly candidate, but even his critics say it raises troubling questions about Romanian democracy.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: As Budget Impasse Grinds On, Macron Appoints a New Cabinet
desc: President Emmanuel Macron of France named the choices less than three weeks after the previous government collapsed. He had already picked François Bayrou as prime minister.
author: By Richard Fausset and Aurelien Breeden

header: Russia Unleashes Another Wave of Attacks on Ukraine
desc: Moscow again struck Ukraine’s energy infrastructure, part of an effort to wear down the country. “In the trenches, there are no holidays,” one man said.
author: By Marc Santora and Liubov Sholudko

header: Pope Francis’ Christmas Message Calls for Peace Amid War
desc: Pope Francis called for cease-fires for the conflicts in Ukraine and in the Middle East during his Christmas message in St. Peter’s Square in Vatican City.
author: By The Associated Press and Reuters

header: Russia Sentences U.S. Citizen to 15 Years for Espionage
desc: Eugene Spector was already serving a sentence for a bribery conviction when he was charged with spying, for which a court ordered him to serve an additional 13 years.
author: By Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: Pope Calls for Peace on Christmas as Church Begins Jubilee Year Celebrations
desc: Pope Francis’ Christmas message was a plea for reconciliation, peace and care for others.
author: By Elisabetta Povoledo

header: Is a Putin Ally in Eastern Europe Making a Cautious Overture to the West?
desc: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus keeps arresting political opponents, but analysts wonder if a string of unusual pardons is a bid to get sanctions eased.
author: By Nataliya Vasilyeva and Andrew Higgins

header: Around the World, Lights and Color Mark the Season
desc: Around the world, people found ways to show their holiday spirit.
author: By Keith Bedford and Sara Ruberg

header: Released From a Russian Prison, This Activist Got Right to Work
desc: Vladimir Kara-Murza, a vehement critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, didn’t want to be part of a prisoner exchange. But he says more exchanges are needed.
author: By Valerie Hopkins

header: He Inherited a Seat in Britain’s House of Lords. How Will It Feel to Lose It?
desc: The U.K. government has pledged to remove hereditary peers from Parliament in 2025. For Lord Cromwell and 87 others, it is a wistful departure.
author: By Mark Landler

header: A Visual Guide to the Tangled Alliances and Rivalries in Syria
desc: After the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, old alliances have crumbled, and global powers are figuring out their relationships with Syria’s new de facto leaders.
author: By Josh Holder, Vivian Yee and Samuel Granados

header: Ukraine Slows Firing of Missiles Into Russia as Trump Prepares to Take Office
desc: The long-range missiles provided by the United States and Britain were used to strike inside Russian territory, despite concerns that their use would escalate the conflict. Kyiv’s stockpiles are running out.
author: By Kim Barker, Lara Jakes, Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Julian E. Barnes

header: What We Know About the Ship Finland Seized Over Fears of Sabotage
desc: Finland seized an oil tanker that authorities believe might have deliberately cut vital undersea cables. Finnish authorities believe the tanker may be linked to Russia.
author: By Johanna Lemola and Lynsey Chutel

header: Finland Says Vessel Suspected of Cutting Cable May Be Part of Russia’s ‘Shadow Fleet’
desc: Finland seized an oil tanker after the latest in a series of disruptions to undersea infrastructure.
author: By Johanna Lemola and Lynsey Chutel

header: What We Know About the Plane Crash in Kazakhstan
desc: The Embraer 190 was traveling to Grozny, Russia, but crashed near Aktau, Kazakhstan, killing 38 people onboard. Investigators are focusing on Russian air defense as the likely cause.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Plane Crash Investigators Focus on Russian Air Defenses as Possible Cause
desc: Russian aviation authorities said the Azerbaijan Airlines plane had hit a flock of birds. But some experts cast doubt on that account, pointing to footage showing apparent holes in the fuselage.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: The Children Who Left Gaza
desc: Sixteen young people evacuated from Gaza for treatment of dire injuries. Months later, they face new lives in an unfamiliar country.
author: By Laura Boushnak and Alan Yuhas

header: The War Killed Her Dreams. To Survive, She Treated Its Fighters.
desc: Trapped in Sudan’s brutal civil war, a young woman chose to work in a clinic on the front line, treating civilians and combatants. She had to navigate suspicion from both sides.
author: By Declan Walsh and Ivor Prickett

header: In Bomb-Scarred Cities, Risking Life and Limb to Get Civilians to Safety
desc: The danger and hardship gets worse by the day for civilians in eastern Ukraine. Still, they resist leaving the places that have become their homes.
author: By Tyler Hicks and Gaëlle Girbes

header: Has Russia’s Shadow Fleet, Built to Evade Sanctions, Added Sabotage to Its List?
desc: Russia has assembled a fleet of hundreds of vessels to covertly ship its oil. With so many ships at sea, the idea of using some to cause havoc may be proving irresistible to the Kremlin.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Putin Apologizes but Stops Short of Taking Responsibility for Kazakhstan Crash
desc: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia told the Azerbaijani leader, Ilham Aliyev, in a phone call, “that the tragic incident took place in Russian airspace.”
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Azerbaijan Blames Russia for Plane Crash and Rebukes Kremlin
desc: The leader of Azerbaijan criticized the Russian response to the crash of a passenger jet that Azerbaijani officials said had most likely been hit by Russian air defenses.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: A Year Both Brutal and Bright: 13 Favorite Dispatches From 2024
desc: In a year marked by wars, extreme weather and general wickedness, many dispatches defaulted to a distinctly dark tone. But as our correspondents traversed the globe, they found pockets of light, too.
author: By Bryant Rousseau

header: Russia and Ukraine Swap More Than 300 Prisoners Ahead of U.S. Transition
desc: Exchanges have taken place before, but this deal, involving big numbers on both sides, comes as Trump prepares to take over in Washington, potentially endangering American aid to Kyiv.
author: By Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: On E-Scooters and ATVs, Russian Forces Swarm Ukrainian Positions in the East
desc: Stepped up attacks by Russia are heightening longstanding concerns over how Ukraine manages its military and countering assumptions that Moscow’s offensive would slow, soldiers and military analysts say.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Putin Declares ‘Everything Will Be Fine’ Despite Russia’s Growing Challenges
desc: Speaking on the 25th anniversary of his rule, President Vladimir V. Putin delivered an upbeat and vague New Year’s Eve message that did not address casualties in Ukraine or rising inflation at home.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev

header: Where Is Russia Finding New Soldiers? Wherever It Can.
desc: From murder suspects to immigrants to a former Olympic gold medalist, Russia pressures those it thinks should fight in Ukraine.
author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

header: New Year’s 2025: Celebrations Around the World
desc: See how people across the globe celebrated.
author: By The New York Times

header: Ukraine Halts the Flow of Natural Gas From Russia to Europe
desc: A transnational pipeline was shut down on Wednesday after Kyiv refused to renew a prewar agreement that allowed for the transit of Russian gas through its territory.
author: By Marc Santora, Andrew Higgins and Jenny Gross

header: Why Did Ukraine Halt the Flow of Russia’s Natural Gas to Europe?
desc: And why didn’t it cut off Russia’s natural gas earlier?
author: By Marc Santora, Andrew Higgins and Stanley Reed

header: Zelensky Expresses Hope for 2025, but Russia Presses On With Attacks
desc: In his New Year’s address, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged continued U.S. support.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Drones, Exploding Parcels and Sabotage: How Hybrid Tactics Target the West
desc: Russia and other hostile states have become increasingly brazen in adopting “gray zone” attacks against Europe and the United States, leaving defense officials with a dilemma: How to respond?
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Italy’s Prime Minister Visits Trump at Mar-a-Lago
desc: Giorgia Meloni, the Italian prime minister, joins just a handful of other world leaders who have been to the president-elect’s Florida estate since his victory.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: Russia Claims Control of Key Town as Ukraine Renews Push in Kursk
desc: Ukraine has largely been driven out of Kurakhove, a battered but strategic town in the Donbas, Russia said. Kyiv’s forces were pressing a renewed offensive in southern Russia.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Ukraine Launches New Attack in Kursk Region of Western Russia
desc: Ukrainian forces’ assault was in the Russian region where they made a surprise incursion last summer.
author: By Marc Santora

header: A Gas Cutoff Sends Shivers Through a Russian-Backed Breakaway Region
desc: A renegade part of Moldova once boasted it would become a Russian-speaking Switzerland. Now without gas, its leader assured residents, “We will not allow a societal collapse.”
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Azerbaijani Anger Over Plane Crash Grows, in Deepening Schism With Russia
desc: In the crash’s aftermath, Azerbaijan has unleashed rare and stinging criticism of Russia, with the country’s president saying Moscow’s response has caused “surprise, regret and rightful indignation.”
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: How Austria Could Get Its First Far-Right Chancellor Since World War II
desc: The leader of the anti-immigration, pro-Russia Freedom Party has been given the chance to try to form a government after months of coalition talks among mainstream parties collapsed.
author: By Christopher F. Schuetze

header: In South Korea, Blinken Affirms Alliance Amid Challenges Facing Democracies
desc: The U.S. secretary of state aimed to show that his country stood by South Korea as it grapples with a political crisis, and as Donald J. Trump returns to power.
author: By Edward Wong and Choe Sang-Hun

header: For Many Returning Russian Veterans, a Long Road of Recovery Awaits
desc: A large number of soldiers return as amputees, and many suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder. Once home, they face stigma and a grueling course of rehabilitation.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

header: Russian Strike Kills 13 in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine
desc: The attack, which also wounded dozens of people, came hours after Ukraine’s military attacked an oil depot deep inside Russia.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Oleksandr Chubko

header: Blinken and Top French Diplomat Criticize Trump’s Talk of Taking Greenland
desc: In Paris, the two officials acknowledged potential strains on alliances with the return of Donald J. Trump to power, but said their countries would try to maintain strong ties.
author: By Edward Wong and Richard Fausset

header: Short of Heat and Power, a Breakaway Region Struggles Without Russian Gas
desc: An energy crisis in Transnistria, a pro-Russian territory between Moldova and Ukraine, erupted on Jan. 1 when Moscow stopped supplying natural gas through a pipeline running across Ukraine.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: A Far-Right Government in Austria Would Be a Jolt, but Not Unexpected
desc: The Freedom Party and its leader, Herbert Kickl, have steadily built support by demonizing immigrants, while entering Austria’s political mainstream.
author: By Jim Tankersley and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Kremlin Confirms Readiness for Putin to Meet Trump
desc: The president-elect had said Russia’s leader wanted to meet him to discuss the war in Ukraine. The Kremlin said it welcomed such dialogue, but a meeting could occur only after Mr. Trump took office.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko

header: Putin Gets a Snub in the Vast Wine Cellars of a Former Soviet Republic
desc: The Russian president celebrated his 50th birthday at a winery in Moldova. After the invasion of Ukraine, it moved the bottles he was given away from public view.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Elon Musk Is Trying to Break Germany’s Quarantine on the Far-Right AfD
desc: Political leaders have shunned the Alternative for Germany. But on his social media platform X, Mr. Musk is pitching the party as mainstream.
author: By Jim Tankersley

header: Egypt’s Economy Is Damaged. It Sees a Scapegoat, and a Potential Fix, in Refugees.
desc: Palestinians, Sudanese and Syrians fleeing war have found a home in the country. But Cairo says newcomers are straining resources and is seeking financial help from the West.
author: By Vivian Yee

header: The Painting, the Photograph and the War for Ukraine’s Culture
desc: An image depicting a famous 19th-century painting of Cossacks, with current Ukrainian soldiers standing in for the warriors, has struck a chord as Kyiv battles to assert its identity.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Ukraine Says It Captured 2 North Korean Soldiers Fighting for Russia
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky said the soldiers were captured in the western Kursk region, where Ukraine has been fighting to hold on to territory it seized last summer.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Battles Rage Inside Russia, With Waves of Tanks, Drones and North Koreans
desc: Ukrainian soldiers are describing fierce clashes as Russian forces try to retake territory in the Kursk region that could be key in eventual cease-fire talks.
author: By Marc Santora, Liubov Sholudko and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Ukraine Launches ‘Massive’ Drone Attacks Inside Russia, Officials Say
desc: The barrage appeared to be one of the largest recent assaults in Ukraine’s campaign to damage Russia’s war machine on its home territory.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Troops Captured by Ukraine Provide Rare Glimpse Into North Korea’s Military
desc: Ukraine’s president released a video of the two soldiers being interrogated, revealing they knew little about the war they were sent to fight in.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun

header: For These Teenagers in Ukraine, Hope Arrived at the Stage Door
desc: The students in a summer acting course performed a play set in America, called, “It’s okay!” And it gave them hope that their lives would be OK, too.
author: By Kim Barker and Dzvinka Pinchuk

header: A New Age of American Interference in Europe
desc: Elon Musk and MAGA are already disrupting the status quo, and Europe seems ill-prepared.
author: By Katrin Bennhold

header: Missile Attack Prompts Emergency Power Cuts in Ukraine
desc: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said air defenses had shot down at least 30 missiles from a “massive” barrage that had targeted gas and energy facilities.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: U.K. Leader Vows Long-Term Partnership With Ukraine on Kyiv Visit
desc: Prime Minister Keir Starmer signaled continued solidarity, with further U.S. support in question under a second Trump administration.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Inside Ukraine’s Last Stand at a Vital Coal Mine
desc: The mine, near the frontline city of Pokrovsk, produced coking coal crucial for Ukraine’s steel industry. It kept running until the very last moment, when Russian forces finally reached its gates.
author: By Constant Méheut, Daria Mitiuk and Finbarr O’Reilly

header: Azerbaijan’s Leader, Emboldened, Picks a Rare Fight With Putin
desc: Russia’s president is said to have blamed birds or a Ukrainian drone for a Dec. 25 crash of an Azerbaijani plane. Azerbaijan says Russian air defenses were at fault.
author: By Anton Troianovski

header: Poland’s Leader Suggests Russian Hand in Plot to Attack Western Cargo Planes
desc: “I can only confirm that Russia planned acts of air terror, not just against Poland but against airlines across the globe,” said Poland’s prime minister, Donald Tusk.
author: By Michael Schwirtz

header: Russia Attacks Kyiv With Ballistic Missiles, Ukraine Says
desc: At least three people were killed in the assault on the capital, and at least one died and 11 were wounded in a separate strike in the southern city of Zaporizhzhia.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd

header: Russia and Iran Sign Cooperation Treaty in the Kremlin
desc: The agreement is focused more on trade than military issues, but it will bring two countries with a shared desire to challenge the West closer together.
author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Farnaz Fassihi

header: The ‘Minister of Everything’ for Justin Trudeau Enters Race to Replace Him
desc: Chrystia Freeland, the former deputy prime minister, sought to distance herself from Mr. Trudeau in a public letter criticizing him for “costly political gimmicks.”
author: By Vjosa Isai

header: 3 Lawyers for Navalny Sentenced for Passing Along His Correspondence
desc: A Russian court said the lawyers for Aleksei Navalny, the country’s top opposition figure before his death in a penal colony last year, were guilty of involvement in an extremist group.
author: By Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: How the Oct. 7 Attacks Transformed the Middle East
desc: With an Israel-Hamas cease-fire set to begin, the shock waves from their war have reshaped the region in unexpected ways.
author: By Erika Solomon

header: Ukraine Braces for Trump’s Return, Eager for Peace, but Wary of the Terms
desc: Soldiers and civilians alike say that after so much loss, the new U.S. president must push for a just settlement, not peace at any cost.
author: By Marc Santora

header: Fighting Alongside Russia, North Koreans Wage Their Own War
desc: Ukrainian forces described a different kind of enemy, fighting with unfamiliar tactics and little option to retreat.
author: By Marc Santora and Helene Cooper

header: Facing Setbacks and Desertions at the Front, Ukraine Detains Commanders
desc: Two generals and a colonel blamed for the loss of territory in eastern Ukraine to Russian forces last year have been held, the country’s security service said.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: As Trump Takes Office, Zelensky Urges Europe to Stand Firm Against Russia
desc: Speaking a day after Trump’s inauguration, Ukraine’s president told world leaders at Davos that Europe needs to remain united and “learn how to take care of itself.”
author: By Marc Santora

header: Britain Says Russian Spy Ship Returned to U.K. Waters in Sign of Kremlin Threat
desc: The British defense secretary told Parliament that the Yantar, which he described as a Russian spy ship, had come near Britain’s coast for the second time in a few months.
author: By Stephen Castle and Michael Schwirtz

header: Europe Braces for a New Trump Era, Uncertain About What It Means
desc: President Trump appears willing to shake up almost every policy area, and a behind-the-scenes E.U. task force has been trying to prepare. But is Europe ready?
author: By Jeanna Smialek

header: Houthis Free the Crew of a Cargo Ship They Hijacked 14 Months Ago
desc: The Iranian-backed rebel group in Yemen had earlier said they would scale back attacks given the cease-fire in the conflict in Gaza.
author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg

header: Trump’s Hint at Deal Making Gives China a Little Breathing Room
desc: Whether it is over TikTok, fentanyl or trade, Beijing might welcome a compromise to buy time to address its ailing economy and bolster its position globally.
author: By David Pierson

header: Clinton Bailey, Who Documented a Vanishing Bedouin Culture, Dies at 88
desc: Armed with a camera and tape recorder, he spent decades preserving the ancient traditions of nomadic Middle Eastern tribes.
author: By Isabel Kershner

header: Did Ukraine Kill Its Own by Downing a Russian Plane? A Year Later, It Hasn’t Said.
desc: Russia says Ukraine shot down a military transport carrying 65 captured Ukrainians. Ukraine has not confirmed its role, identified the bodies it received, or said how it happened.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Maria Varenikova

header: Ukraine Is Losing Fewer Soldiers Than Russia — but It’s Still Losing the War
desc: Russia has lost about twice as many men to death and serious injury as Ukraine. But the trends favor the Kremlin.
author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and Constant Méheut

header: With Support Dwindling and Trump in Power, Zelensky Could Face Tough Re-election
desc: The high popularity that the Ukrainian president had in the early days of the Russian invasion, with an approval rating of about 90 percent, has dipped badly.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Kenneth P. Vogel

header: Ukraine Sends Volley of Drones at Russia, Hitting Oil Refinery
desc: Videos showed fireballs over a facility in Ryazan, 110 miles southeast of Moscow. Kyiv is seeking to disrupt Russian military logistics and put pressure on the country’s economy by striking its oil industry.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Trump Is Leading a Global Surge to the Right
desc: But not all of the leading conservative populist parties in the world are the same — in rhetoric or on policy.
author: By Jim Tankersley, Emma Bubola, Andrew Higgins and Aurelien Breeden

header: Trump Hints at New Talks With Kim Jong-un. It Might Be Harder This Time.
desc: North Korea’s leader has grown more assertive since their last efforts at diplomacy ended in failure — and now has Russia at his side.
author: By Choe Sang-Hun

header: A Storm, a Spill and a Disaster for the Black Sea’s Beaches
desc: Vast stretches of Russian coast have been tarred by heavy fuel oil from two freighters that foundered in a storm.
author: By Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: Belarus’s Strong-Arm Leader, Aleksandr Lukashenko, Cruises to Re-election
desc: Europe’s longest-serving leader won re-election in a contest widely believe to have been rigged. The result cements the power of a leader whose country is considered Russia’s staunchest ally.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: His Opponents Sidelined, Lukashenko Is Set for a 7th Term in Belarus
desc: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, a close ally of Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin, has been making signs of reaching out to the West. He is all but certain to win an election on Sunday.
author: By Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: Europe Is Pouring Money Into Defense. Is It Enough?
desc: With a full-blown land war in Ukraine and an isolationist American president back in the White House, European leaders have come to a stark conclusion: They must spend more on their militaries.
author: By Josh Holder

header: Trump Alarms Denmark in an Icy Exchange Over Greenland
desc: President Trump told Denmark’s leader he wanted to take over Greenland, European officials say. Denmark has asked its E.U. allies not to inflame the situation until Mr. Trump’s intentions are clearer.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Jeanna Smialek

header: Here’s a Closer Look at the 4 Released Hostages
desc: The young women freed on Saturday were working as “spotters” for Israel’s army when they were abducted in the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7, 2023.
author: By Natan Odenheimer, Ephrat Livni, Talya Minsberg, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Lynsey Chutel

header: As Hamas Exchanges Gaza Hostages, It Puts on a Show of Force
desc: The handover of four female Israeli soldiers by Hamas on Saturday came as Israel released 200 prisoners. But a dispute arose over the hostage release timetable.
author: By Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon and Thomas Fuller

header: Israel Welcomes the Return of the Women Who Warned of a Raid From Gaza
desc: Young female “spotters” for Israel’s army reported suspicious activity across the border. When Hamas attacked, 15 were killed and seven abducted. Four came home on Saturday.
author: By Isabel Kershner

header: Many Ukrainian Aid Groups Stop Work After Trump’s Halt on Foreign Assistance
desc: The Trump administration’s orders have sent a chill through humanitarian organizations in Ukraine, which depend heavily on such assistance.
author: By Maria Varenikova and Constant Méheut

header: Standoff at Ukrainian Procurement Agency Threatens to Disrupt Weapons Supply
desc: Ukraine’s defense minister fired the head of a state agency that acquired over $7 billion in armaments last year, citing “unsatisfactory” results. But, the official vowed to remain.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: As Trump and Putin Circle Each Other, an Agenda Beyond Ukraine Emerges
desc: President Trump jabs at the Russian leader with threats; Vladimir Putin responds with flattery. But there are notable signals in their jousting, including a revived discussion about nuclear arms control.
author: By David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski

header: Chastened by Past Wars, Kremlin Tries to Elevate Its Veterans
desc: Russians who fought in Chechnya and Afghanistan came home to silence and stigma. There’s a very public push to make things different this time.
author: By Valerie Hopkins and Alina Lobzina

header: At Auschwitz, a Solemn Ceremony at a Time of Rising Nationalism
desc: World leaders and a dwindling group of survivors joined in a ceremony to mark the 80th anniversary of the liberation of the Nazi death camp by the Red Army.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Sweden Suspects ‘Gross Sabotage’ After Damage to Cable Under Baltic Sea
desc: The Nordic country has opened an investigation into the damage, just weeks after NATO stepped up its military presence in the area following a series of similar incidents.
author: By Christina Anderson and Amelia Nierenberg

header: Confronted by Trump, Denmark Looks to Its European Neighbors for Support
desc: The prime minister does a European tour while announcing more spending on security around the island, following President Trump’s stated desire to have Greenland, a semiautonomous Danish territory, as part of the U.S.
author: By Steven Erlanger and Lynsey Chutel

header: Gaza and Lebanon Truces Are Fragile, but All Sides May Keep Them Going
desc: Bloodshed over the weekend highlighted the brittleness of the cease-fires in both places. Still, Israel, Hamas and Hezbollah each have reasons to postpone a new escalation, at least for a few weeks.
author: By Patrick Kingsley

header: Serbian Leader, Trying to Quell Protests, Jettisons a Key Ally
desc: Demonstrations around Serbia pose a challenge to the decade-long hold on power by President Aleksandar Vucic, who spurred his prime minister to step down.
author: By Andrew Higgins

header: Germany’s Likely Leader Flirts With a Taboo: Working With the Far Right
desc: Responding to the killing of a child, the poll-leading Christian Democrats are pushing to overhaul migration laws — possibly with votes from the Alternative for Germany.
author: By Jim Tankersley and Christopher F. Schuetze

header: Russia Seizes Another Ukrainian Town in Push to Take All of Donetsk
desc: Moscow’s troops used the same pincer tactic on Velyka Novosilka that has enabled their recent capture of town after town in eastern Ukraine.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Kyiv Mayor Feuds With Zelensky in Schism Over Martial Law
desc: The mayor, Vitali Klitschko, who has had a tense relationship with President Volodymyr Zelensky, accused him of trying to usurp the powers of elected officials in the capital.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: North Korean Troops No Longer Seen on Front Lines Fighting Ukraine
desc: North Korea sent its best troops to aid Russia in its war against Ukraine. But after months of suffering severe losses, they have been taken off the front line.
author: By Michael Schwirtz and Julian E. Barnes

header: How Does DeepSeek’s A.I. Chatbot Navigate China’s Censors? Awkwardly.
desc: Asked about sensitive topics, the bot would begin to answer, then stop and delete its own work. It refused to answer questions like: “Who is Xi Jinping?”
author: By Vivian Wang

header: A U.K. Teen Became Fixated on Extreme Violence. But Was It Terrorism?
desc: Axel Rudakubana, who killed three girls in a stabbing spree at a dance class, was obsessed with violence but had no known ideology. His case has led to calls for a rethink of counterterror strategy.
author: By Lizzie Dearden

header: How the World Is Reeling From Trump’s Aid Freeze
desc: President Trump’s order to halt most foreign aid has intensified humanitarian crises and raised questions about the United States’ reliability as a global leader.
author: By Sui-Lee Wee, Declan Walsh and Farnaz Fassihi

header: Norway Seizes Russian-Crewed Ship Suspected of Cutting an Undersea Cable
desc: The authorities said they believed the vessel may have been involved in damaging the cable, the latest act of apparent sabotage in the Baltic Sea.
author: By Henrik Pryser Libell and Lynsey Chutel

header: Kremlin Chokes YouTube Service, but Russians Find Ways Around It
desc: The Kremlin is trying to cripple YouTube in Russia, internet experts say, pushing some people to state-controlled domestic alternatives. But many Russians have found workarounds.
author: By Paul Sonne

header: Egypt Fears Syria’s Revolutionary Fervor Could Be Contagious
desc: Since Islamist rebels overthrew the Assad dictatorship in Syria, Egypt, with parallels in its own recent history, has watched warily.
author: By Vivian Yee

header: Trump Urges Trading Ukraine’s Critical Minerals for More U.S. Aid
desc: Ukraine has already emphasized that by supporting its war effort, the U.S. could get access to the country’s wealth of critical minerals like lithium and uranium.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Ukraine Says at Least 18 Civilians Are Killed in Strikes
desc: At least 14 people were killed in Poltava, Ukrainian officials said, blaming Russia. Four died in Sudzha, a Russian town held by Ukraine, in a strike each country blamed on the other.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Standoff at Ukrainian Agency Disrupts Arms Contracts, Suppliers Say
desc: Ukrainian defense companies say they cannot sign new contracts or receive payment — potentially jeopardizing future supplies to already struggling troops.
author: By Constant Méheut

header: Pro-Russia Ukrainian Is Killed in Moscow Blast, Russian Media Says
desc: Armen Sarkisyan, the founder of a separatist battalion fighting in eastern Ukraine, died after an explosion in an apartment complex, according to reports citing the Russian authorities.
author: By Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: With Trump’s Backing Uncertain, Europe Scrambles to Shore Up Its Own Defenses
desc: European leaders gathered Monday to plot a rough path forward on defense. Wavering support from President Trump is driving the debate.
author: By Jeanna Smialek and Steven Erlanger

header: Rescuers Search for Survivors After Missile Strike in Ukraine
desc: Ukrainian officials said at least 14 people were killed in Poltava, Ukraine, after a Russian missile hit a residential building in the city, which is nearly 150 miles from the front lines.
author: By Reuters

header: For China, Trump’s Moves Bring Pain, but Also Potential Gains
desc: President Trump’s tariffs hurt China, but his other actions have alienated U.S. allies, giving Beijing an opening to strengthen its global standing.
author: By David Pierson, Keith Bradsher and Sui-Lee Wee

header: 3 Mexican Sectors Most Affected by U.S. Tariffs, and How the Country Could Respond
desc: President Trump’s tariffs will have major effects on Mexico’s auto industry, agriculture and energy, but the country has some means for responding.
author: By Simon Romero

header: French Government Survives No-Confidence Vote
desc: The vote clears the way for final approval of France’s 2025 budget, easing concerns about the country’s political turmoil — but not ending them.
author: By Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter

header: Foreign Strongmen Cheer as Musk Dismantles U.S. Aid Agency
desc: Leaders in Russia, Hungary and El Salvador welcomed the Trump administration’s assault on U.S.A.I.D., which many authoritarians have seen as a threat.
author: By Paul Sonne

header: Allies and foes decry Trump’s plan: ‘Out of the question.’
desc: NA
author: By Lara Jakes

header: Trump’s Gaza Takeover Would Violate International Law, Experts Say
desc: Forcing Palestinians to leave the enclave would be “a straightforward crime against humanity,” an Oxford professor said. It would be a further violation to take over the territory.
author: By Amanda Taub

header: These Are the Major Obstacles to Trump’s Gaza Plan
desc: The politically explosive proposal to move Palestinians out of Gaza and remake it as a U.S. territory included few details. Experts say it ignores the political dynamics of the region and would probably violate international law.
author: By Peter Baker, Patrick Kingsley, Amanda Taub, Qasim Nauman, Lara Jakes, Aaron Boxerman, Michael Crowley and Cassandra Vinograd

header: To Keep Aid Coming, Ukraine Appeals to Trump Allies: Conservative Christians
desc: A Ukrainian delegation to the National Prayer Breakfast in Washington will make the case that Russia threatens the religious freedom of Christians who don’t follow the Russian Orthodox Church.
author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Lara Jakes

header: At a Draft Site in Ukraine, an Anguished Wait for a Chance to Say Goodbye
desc: The Ukrainian authorities are rounding up recruits. Relatives huddle at a center on the edge of Kyiv for a chance to see loved ones before they’re shipped to war.
author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Oleksandr Chubko

header: An American Teacher Went to Ukraine. Now He’s in a Russian Prison.
desc: Stephen Hubbard was a wanderer. But when he moved to Ukraine, the war brought arrest, torture and imprisonment. He turns 73 this week.
author: By Kim Barker and Nataliya Vasilyeva

header: How War Has Wreaked Havoc on Ukraine’s Classrooms
desc: Students have been forced to attend classes underground or online, especially in regions near the front line. Experts say that Ukrainian children are falling behind as a result, academically and socially.
author: By Maria Varenikova

header: Trump’s Foreign Aid Freeze Has Created Chaos. Here Is What to Know.
desc: Critics say a Trump administration order calls into question the United States’ global standing and reliability.
author: By Yonette Joseph, Malika Khurana and Adam Pasick

header: Angela Merkel Is Retired. But She’s Still on the Ballot.
desc: If anything unites the parties in Germany’s election campaign, it is running away from the former chancellor, whose legacy voters have soured on.
author: By Jim Tankersley

header: Far-Right Leaders Rally in Spain to ‘Make Europe Great Again’
desc: At a gathering in Madrid, members of Europe’s far-right parties set aside any trepidation they might have about President Trump’s threats and instead focused on a common enemy: the European Union.
author: By Emma Bubola

header: Can European ‘Boots on the Ground’ Help Protect Ukraine’s Security?
desc: Deterring Russia from re-invading Ukraine, once this war ends, could require 150,000 troops and American help with air cover, intelligence and missile defense, experts say.
author: By Steven Erlanger

header: U.N. Suspends Humanitarian Work in Yemeni Area After Houthis Detain More Staff
desc: The total employees arrested since 2021 has risen to 24, a U.N. spokesman said. The Iran-backed Houthis have held them on murky charges of espionage and foreign intervention.
author: By Farnaz Fassihi

header: Vance, in First Foreign Speech, Tells Europe That U.S. Will Dominate A.I.
desc: Speaking in Paris at an artificial intelligence summit, the vice president gave an America First vision of the technology — with the U.S. dominating the chips, the software and the rules.
author: By David E. Sanger

header: Germany’s Would-Be Chancellor Tries to Get Back on Cruise Control
desc: Dogged by protesters, but apparently safe from damage in the polls, Friedrich Merz is putting a failed immigration gambit behind him.
author: By Jim Tankersley and Tatiana Firsova
